content:
ry 3, 2014
												Six hours into the game and I really like it so far. Playing it feels like having an adventure in the Warcraft universe with Fable gameplay. The world and the range of quests is big enough to get your money's worth - you just have to overlook the MMO-like style of the majority of missions (go there, get that, fight this, come back) and the tubular area design. I really enjoy the graphic style - as I said, it really reminds me of the Warcraft franchise. The game's environmental design is full of variety (unfortunately, the enemies are not) and really nice to look at. You just have to look up to see the game's beauty, because the standard camera angle is somewhat pointed downwards for some reason. I can't say too much about the story yet, but even though it is that classic "chosen one saves kingdom against all odds" scenario, you realise pretty soon that it is rather well written and in accord with the atmospheric world.The game's difficulty can be adjusted at any time. I started on "hard" since a friend told me that it was too easy. I had a fairly challanging run until I got some better gear, which made most fights beside boss-battles pretty redundant. On the other side,I think the difficulty really depends on the zone you are in, so don't let this repel you too much.I play it with a controller and it works fine. The camera is a little tardy but that is all I can complain about right now.All in all, you notice really soon that, even though this is a whole new franchise, experienced minds were working on this title.It is a worthwhile, light fantasy experience (having the three classic classes to choose from, or just fusion two/three of them) with a really nice graphical style (in my opinion at least). Recommended for fans of the Fable series or people that are looking for a game of this kind in a Warcraft-like setting. Worth the price if you put some time in to it, and definitely worth the money when on sale. 7.5/10

content:
ry 6, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is an outstanding game, I was never a fan of the elder scrolls series(And I gave em all fair chances), but just couldn't get into them. This game I feel is better in many ways. Good 1) When you die you don't have to start all the way back at the last town you were at or where you last saved.2) You don't have to save before going into a dungeon or going off to explore.3) The grapics are outstanding along with the music.4) Also you don't have to take 1 whole hour to adjust your toon.The list can go on! Bad 1) The camera can get a bit glitchy and can sometimes be covered up by stuff like grass and plants.2) The sound can get glitchy / cutoff depending on region. There's a solution in the guides.3) Enemies can get repetitive Overall Outstanding music and graphics but can be glitchy, no need for many save files, Enemies can get repetivite. 4/5

content:
ry 24, 2014
												This is an amazing little gem, it has all of the characteristics of an early Skyrim but it is simple enough to play, I would recommend this game because of the playability which is second to none.  Its really easy to pick up and you can play to how you prefer to play it in terms of fighting style, there are 3 base classes to choose from, which in turn, each have a complex tree of varying combinations of classes.  The world you play in is a very vibrant one, full of colour and texture.  There is alchemy, blacksmithing, you can upgrade certain weapons and armor and best of all, for all lovers of RPG's, there's plenty of loot.  Money is scarce at first but after a dozens missions or so under your belt and you will see how quickly your money can build up.  You can level up your character, choose as you will because you can always change completely at anytime by visiting Fateweavers who will, for price, reset your levels so that you can rebuild to a different style.

content:
ry 7, 2014
												I will openly admit that I had absolutely no intention originally of ever picking this game up... until it went on sale majorly discounted (Thank you, Steam!) and a friend told me to just give it a shot. I have to say, I rather enjoy it very much and I am kicking myself for not giving it a shot before. The artstyle for this is what hit me first. It has such a bright and colorful atmosphere while still being able to be dark when it needs to be. I find myself looking around each and every new area I visit rather thuroughly and not being disappointed in the least. The designs of the characters, items and equipment are also very unique and the fact that Todd McFarlane had his hands in it really shows.It has a story that really draws you in and it has such an ambiguous morality meter that you really feel your impacts on the world. the gameplay is just as fun and addictive as well adding a unique combo and weapon swap ability that just works and the magic use itself is spectacular. It is not without it's faults though as I found the quests themselves rather repetative. Other than that, it is definitely worth the full price that it is. :) 8.5/10

content:
ry 23, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning delivers exactly what it promises: a pitch-perfect fantasy RPG, with visceral, intuitive gameplay that is easy to pick up, difficult to master, wildly flexible and just plain fun, in a way that has yet to be seen in the genre. The world is accessible and vast, offering genre fans plenty to sink their teeth into. One gets the sense that they are watching an entire world unfold before them, one rich with history and lore and life. Amalur opens itself up to the player in a way that is both familiar and refreshing, then empowers the player to do incredible things. 38 Studios and Big Huge Games have created a world worth saving, and they have given us some pretty damn cool tools with which to get the job done.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												This game is really good. The graphics have that sort of fantasy vibe to it, although it's not really at a good resolution. I'm not sure how you change the resolution either. There doesn't seem to be any graphics options that let you change it. That's very bad. Very very bad. My monitor is a 1680x1050 and it looks a bit washed out with this resolution. I can still play it, but I just wish I could change some of the graphics options.Edit: Upon further inspection, the only time you can change the graphics options are in the main menu. The gameplay is pure hack-and-slash fun. Think of games like Darksiders. That is kind of this game (minus the epic areial combos). This game is also a loot-fest. You get new equipment very frequently (if you take the time to explore). All the weapons are really fun to use and have different strengths and weaknesses to them, like the daggers being the fast and low-damage type, hammers which are the slow but hard-hitting type, typical etc. etc.. You also can do numerous special moves that you unlock with each weapon type. You also have this fate weaving ability (forgot what it was called) where you press and hold the triggers (or the keyboard equivalent) to slow down time and kill your enemies faster and impale them to death with large energy spears...Hmm. Yes. Overall, very fun and engaging combat.The story is alright, it's not cliche, but it's nothing to write home about. You are basically the vitcim of a war, and you have died. Yes, you heard me right. You died. But don't fret, something called the well of life resurrected you. I don't really know anything else because I most likely have forgotten. The voice acting is also quite good. Not Skyrim levels, but still it's not gut wrenchingly bad.The only thing that I would have had improved is the user interface. The inventory system feels very cluttered and since your items are featured on one page in a sort of list structure, albiet seperated in categories, it's hard to navigate. I wish they would've shown all of your items on the single screen instead of having to scroll down to see which new items you have acquired, or want to equip, etc. Also the camera kind of sucks, it's very close sometimes, and then sometimes it's further away.Overall, I like this game and would reccommend anyone who likes games like Skyrim or Darksiders to pick this up. Though not at full price.

content:
ry 4, 2014
												I am still trying to figure out why I hadn't heard of this game. Upon further study, I realize it's because I was too busy with Skyrim... However, this game is on-par with skyrim when it comes to playability and fun and I'm sad I missed it. I would have payed full price for it. Ended up getting it during the 2014 winter sale.The visual style and combat is nothing like skyrim. In my opinion, the combat in skyrim is more fun only because you can make it as challenging as you want. People say this game is easy, and they're not lying. If you're looking for a harder experience start out pure mage. If the combat was harder, it would far surpass skyrims system. The flow of it is very fun and worth it even despite it's easiness, which should say alot about it. The quests are fun and rewarding, and the loot/equipment system is more akin to Diablo than Elder Scrolls. Some people will like that, and some people won't. I love it. The alchemy and blacksmithing system is awesome, and it gives you a reason to go around collecting raegents and tools. In fact, I can't think of an RPG Alchemy system that did it more right. I'd say they even have the Witcher beat when it comes to that. All in all, highly recommended if you're a fan of RPGs. I didn't want to spend too much time comparing this game to skyrim and failed heavily, but Elder Scrolls are one of my favorite game series on the planet and this game is right up there. Looking forward to more playtime!

content:
ry 25, 2015
A cohesive narrative and vibrant visuals bring the world of Amalur to life.As I glance through some other user reviews I see a lot of positive comparisons to some of the leaders of the RPG genre: Skyrim, Guild Wars 2, Fable, Diablo and Torchlight. Personally I saw the closest resemblance to World of Warcraft with its visuals and questing system. However, this is no clone of a game. It has a unique identity that, in part, is made from borrowing successful traits from these other titles. What stands out most strongly to me about Kingdoms of Amalur is its narrative and world lore. It presents fresh ideas and throughout my 95+ hours (including 210 quests completed) with the game it always felt consistent, like the developers shared a unified vision of what they wanted this world to be.Without discussing any specific plot points, I'll say that things begin on a high note and intrigued me right off the bat with a mystery surrounding who this character you are playing as is. It is a special feat in my mind to be able to have a personalized, voiceless protagonist that you are expected to project yourself into also have a predetermined, very interesting back story of their own. Too often these types of characters are just a boring blank slate. My sense of progression through this world was wonderful. Your journey begins far from a major warzone and consequently you merely hear stories about it. As you advance closer you begin to see more immediate effects like sons and daughters gone off to fight or altered local economies. Eventually you'll see large refugee camps causing overcrowding problems and burned down towns before reaching the warfront itself. By and large, the settings you visit along the way stand apart from each other both visually and in local story. The exceptions to this are some of the dungeons that look and play very similarly, just with different layouts and quest objectives to fulfill. For a game already so big I think it would have benefited from cutting some of them out.All dialogue is voice acted and of good quality. There is some noticeable reuse of voice actors among NPCs, but that is excusable for a game of this size. I would rather see good voice actors reused than bad voice actors brought in in greater numbers.Combat, unfortunately, is just adequate. There isn't enough depth here to stay compelling throughout. There is a nice mix of weapon types that all control very differently, but you're likely to pick one or two early on and stick with them. Magic brings some cool spells to the fray but are very limited in number. Leveling up is a good, customizable system that does gradually add new abilities, but not enough to keep things from going stale. To be clear, I never got to a point of hating battles. However, a combination of things getting too easy by the end, the long length of the game and repetition of enemy types eventually sucked a lot of the enjoyment out of it. I will warn you that it is possible to become over leveled if you do all side quests as you find them. Google "Amalur Wiki overlevel" to find a guide for avoiding this.I'll wrap things up with a few more minor critiques. Loot is dealt out in such volume that inventory management becomes a chore (similar to many Diabloesque games). Despite this abundance of gear it was surprisingly infrequent how often I found something better than what I was wearing. Also, before long I had more money than things to do with it. I play most games on Normal difficulty, including this one, but didn't find enough challenge here so I suggest playing on Hard to most players. The orchestral score was competently produced but lacked the artistry to make it memorable.Overall, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a fantastic, expansive experience that could have benefited from seeing its great length reined in a little bit.

												So I heard this game was a massive flop, and that made me dubious about picking it up, but the sale this weekend was too much to pass on, and I grabbed it. 10 hours or so in now and I honestly can't see why this wasn't game of the year 2012. It's like someone took the combat from Fable, made it actually good and moderately challenging, and then took the idea of massive open environments to explore, chucked some sick Briton mythology in there for giggles and then wrapped it up with some top tier writing and dialogue. The best way I can think of describing it would be if The Elder Scrolls and Fable had a baby, and it was ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, with the sick quests of Oblivion and Morrowind combined with the combat style of Fable, but made way deeper and with enemies that aren't completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Basically if you took all the disappointment from Skyrim and Fable 3, and made the opposite.I mean sure, it ain't Dark Souls if you're looking for something super hard, but many of the fights I've already encountered would wreck you if you did them wrong.

ber 21, 2014
GREAT GAME! It's a sad thing that the company that made this masterpiece was put into bankruptcy because of poor planning. They should have gotten more hype on it because it's such a well-done game despite what you might hear from some people.The combat is 8/10.Why? The camera angles, dear god, but the combat itself is amazing. The movements are smooth, not jerky, and can get really fast paced if you play right.The lore is 10/10.Why? It's so developed, that there's no obvious problems with it. You would have to do some serious research to find contradictions and plot-holes.The UI is 9.9/10.Why? Because you can't zoom the minimap in or out, I'd really love to see that change, but it will never come.Should you buy this game? HELL YEAH!There's about 300 HOURS... H-O-U-R-S... of gameplay and story. You will never get bored as easy as you would get bored with other games in the same genre.If you want to know something cool, this game WAS going to be an MMO, but it shut down before that. If ANY professional video game development teams every find themselves lacking a project, TAKE THIS UP!You can buy the IP from Rhode Island and get to work immediately and possibly create a well-deserved sequel.Don't let me down, this game shouldn't have been left to rot.

A RPG with surprises!The Story is simple but not linear.You, a soldier, died in a battle against the Tuatha (bad guys). Some gnomes revived you... and you start your journey. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 7, 2014
												I went into this game after being very frustrated by aspects of Divinity 2. Kingdoms of Amalur turned out to be a far more satisfying experience, albeit in unexpected ways.A major selling point is that it was written by R.A. Salvatore, one of my favourite authors. However, the game's story is very forgettable. I mean that literally - I've played 60 hours, am nearly at the end, and can barely remember anything that's happened. There is a great set piece battle and a few clever side quests, but the rest just blurs together - something something "fate", something something "mortal". There's few choices and little reason to even read the dialogue most of the time - just follow the quest markers and do what the pop-up text tells you to do.What it really gets right is the gameplay. Combat is varied enough to keep things interesting, despite making up the bulk of the gameplay. Enemies flail around when set on fire, dodge arrows, resist some forms of damage and have some neat skills and spells. The player character can be built in several different ways , and the paths are distinct enough to encourage re-specing (which is quite easy to do). Controls are straightforward, although the camera can be bothersome at times.The inability to jump, with the resulting unpassable ankle-high obstacles, is irritating at first, but moving around the world is simple enough through a generous fast-travel system, and there's plenty to do as you walk around.There's no shortage of loot, both from enemy drops and in numerous chests and hidden locations. The inventory fills up annoyingly quickly, with no option to screen items by quality, but there's no shortage of merchants around.The crafting system is great, allowing all sorts of equipment, potions and gems to be made.The game loads quickly, and looks lovely even on a mid-range system.There's certainly plenty of gameplay - expect 60 or more hours to complete most of the sidequests.It's a shame the game will never be followed up, because there is an excellent core game here.

content:
29, 2016
												Large, enjoyable, underrated action-rpg. Fun, button-mashy combat that still requires some attention/strategy (esp. on hard); pretty good amount of loot; interesting skill trees and character advancement options; semi-sorta-open-world (new chunks of world unlock as you progress deeper into the game). Gameplay is smooth, responsive, and satisfying, though I recommend using a gamepad for this one. Graphics aren't cutting edge, but they're decent. The world, on the whole, is nicely varied and fun to just roam about and button-mash in. On the downside, the world is pretty superficial compared to something like a Bethesda game. There's plenty of lore and subquests and dialogue trees and all of that, but none of it is very involving -- just kind of par for the course, more of a console-game feel to the progression and atmosphere. I can't really fault the game much beyond that, though. It's a really solid game, just don't expect quite the level of depth you'd get from a hardcore open-world PC rpg. At the time I'm writing this it's on sale for under $10, and it's a great get for that price.

content:
y 30, 2014
												This is one of those underrated games that got overshadowed by Skyrim because they came out around the same time, and the company was pretty new and unknown. But there are major differences between Kingdoms and Skyrim most noteably, Kingdoms doesn't freeze, get lost, or crash like Skyrim does, especially the xbox version. HOWEVER this game was made for Windows 7, and the company didn't survive, which stinks btw... so there are crashes on Windows 10. Every time I tried to play this game on W10 it did crash after about 15 minutes of play, and others have said the same...so if you don't run Windows 7...you may want to pass on this one, even though it is a really great game.Kingdoms is really well written, engaging, and fun to explore. The map is huge, AND most importantly, its easy to follow. There are a lot of cool features like  dispel chests which are challenging to unlock but hold a lot of valuable stuff in them. Although learning to open them can be a real pain in the fanny because if you fail, you suffer health loss, but they will still be unlocked. There are chests to find, tons of them...and lore stones that when you find and activate them, they reveal narration of the backstory. There is a lot going for this game, it's visually beautiful, reminiscent of Fable, but also holds its own original story and style, and great music, and so is the voice acting. The combat is fun with lots of weapons, spells, etc, to aid you. But the best feature of this game is the combat because it doesn't require the player to be at a high level before they get powerful weapons and spells. You get that pretty darn early so that is a plus in my book. There are 3 game difficulty levels, and several races to choose and build your character from male and female. Human and other.I have logged about 90 hours on this game  (mostly offline not recorded by Steam)... and I still haven't finished everything. There are a ton of side quests but not necessary for leveling up , but can be over-whelming if you start too many at once, which is very easy to do. Basically it is open-world, however the story is linear. The character design and environments were created by Todd McFarlane (creator of Spawn) so ...you know it's great.This really is an overlooked game...but it plays very well, and you should check it out IF you run Windows 7.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												The gameplay of KoA is fantastic. A strong world of warcraft feel to the graphics allows for a smooth gameplay on a poor spec machine.On the world of warcraft note, I would like to add that the entire game feels like it was based off it. The graphocs, quests, locations and characters are all very similar to wow. That aside, there is a lot of orginality in the game, with decent voice acting, the combat system and the smithing concept.My ratings for the game:Audio: 9/10 - Ambient soundtrack was done well, allowing for smooth transitions between combat and adventuring. The voice acting was done really well. No faults in my opinion, didn't get 10/10 because I wouldn't purchase the soundtrack just to listen to it.Visual: 9/10 - As mentioned above, the visuals are smooth and familiar.Gameplay and Content: 10/10 - There is enough in game that I feel that I definately got my money's worth. I was lucky enough to catch KoA and all of it's DLC during a sale at a bargain price.Replayability: 6/10 - The different classes within the game allow for a HUGE amount of replayability. If you want to mix stealth and magic, there are classes and bonuses to suit. If you want to mix all three aspects, there are classes and bonuses for that too. If you want to focus purely on one aspect, then obviously, there are classes and bonuses for them too. The only problem is, even though I had a great time playing through once, I get bored with it quite quickly when I go to start the game again.All in all, I would definately suggest the game to other people, and have done. I would really like to see 2 player co-op brought into the game, if I'd seen that come through, I don't think I would have to buy another game on steam ever again!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
17, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a colossal and deep RPG with a beautiful atmosphere.The world you can explore is huge, even though it is parted into many little regions which are designed rather linear. However, this makes it easier to find every quest and not to miss something important. There are tons of caves, cities, castles and forests  that are enjoyable to explore. Besides, you can fast-travel to any location you have visited so far, which is a great tool.There are three skilltrees in which you can invest , you do not have to limit your points to one of them. You can mix them up in any way you want to. You will encounter several fateweavers in the game which can reset your skill points for a bit some money, depending on your level. The level cap in this game is 40.The story itself is pretty cool and presented very well but gets a bit lengthy towards the end, yet the ending itself is spectacular again. There are several moments where you can influence certain outcomes with your decisions.There is a extremely large number of available side-quests in this game,  I ended up having completed around 300 of them (with both DLC’s). Some of them go with the standard pattern like finding some reagents or killing some mobs while on the other hand there are some pretty big side-quests that bring a little story on their own which are very entertaining to follow.The game has 3 difficulty-settings and I recommend you to play it on hard since it’s still pretty easy on medium as long as you’re not fighting large groups of enemies, especially towards the end when you got the best kinds of armor and weapons.There is a variety of different enemies that behave different in battle which leads to entertaining fights. The Gameplay itself is pretty good in my eyes,  especially the combats are very dynamic. The graphics are quite good for early 2012 and the world is designed with a love for detail. You’ll find many different environments that feel alive. The great music of this game strengthens the atmosphere even more.On the downside, there are some bugs in this game which will never get fixed because the studio that produced this game went bankrupt. However, most of these bugs just make some quest items being stuck in your inventory after you completed the quest or other minor things that one can oversee.In Amalur, you can acquire various houses in which you can store your items, you can even earn an own arena and a mining company which gain you money over time.There are various weapon types with different advantages and downsides which brings some additional diversity.Regarding the DLC’s, I can greatly recommend you “The Legend of Dead Kel” and “Teeth of Naros”, which both have a great storyline and add another big map part to the already huge map each. However, the “Weapons & Armor Bundle” just adds a bit of loot that falls off quite quick and in my opinion is not worth the money.All in All, I truly recommend giving Kingdoms of Amalur a try, for it a large and beautiful game with a wonderful atmosphere.P.S.: Sorry for my bad English, it’s not my native language.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												I really love this game. It's one of my favorites to play.When I first started playing it, my very first impressions were, 'ok this is nice, kind of like Skyrims poorer cousin', but the more I played the more I realized how unfair that initial thought was.The combat is very fluid, with a great feeling of impact to the hits. All the moves and spells are beautifully animated.I've gone pure warrior on my first character and can't wait to try out the pure caster role as I think it will be different and interesting to play. Rogue types are normally my least fave to play, but the combat is so enjoyable I'm even looking forward to trying that out too.Loads of side quests (I'm aiming to do all of them on my first character.)The world is huge and very nicely done. There are invisible walls but the world is very open and I don't find they get in the way so they're not something to worry about and they've included jump off points at locations where you'd need/want them.The dungeons are great fun too. Loads of loot drops and chests in dungeons and around the world. The weapons and armor are all really nicely meshed and textured as well.The only negative thing I'd say about the world is that there's something not quite right with the ...ambience? When your outside it feels like you're inside, I haven't been able to put my finger on why that is though, maybe the sounds or something. It's not game breaking, just a little weird when you first start playing, it doesn't bother me at all now.The herbing animations are beautiful, which I think shows a really nice attention to detail.The professions in general are all really good and all worth having. The only thing is when your salvaging armor and weapons it can be a bit awkward. It's fine if you only carry round stuff you have equipped and are going to salvage or sell everything else, but I 'collect' stuff, so I'm constantly having to flick back to my inventory and then back to the salvage screen to make sure I'm not salvaging anything I intended to keep. I feel if you could have salvaged directly from your junk inventory that would have been much better. But that's the only negative thing I have to say about this game at all, and overall and compared to everything else they got right, it's not at all important, just inconvenient......for me :PI enjoy this game so much that I did a search to see what other games the company had made, and was really sad to see that they went bust shortly after this game was released. This game seems to have flown 'under the radar' which is ashame since it should have kept the company in business. I'm surprised KoA is not better known than it is. I bought KoA and all the dlcs when it was on sale here at steam, but it's definitely worth it's full asking price.

ry 2, 2014
												Holy crap this game is fun!  Dont compare it to Skyrim or similar games and you'll be pleased...that is if you like fast paced and intense combat, deep storyline, alchemy, crafting, and great voice acting/diversion. Has a nice spread of all the RPG elements so your not doing too much of any one thing.  Reckoning is simplified in ways that makes it easy to play without getting bogged down by realistic elements such as arrow counts (which I actually like...as in Skyrim), but is very well suited for this type of game.  It was designed for simplicity and even though its open world still feels linear, but again..keeps a smooth flow and makes it easy to play without having to over think or worry about getting lost (for example). All the other reviews are true!...they did wonders for the inventory organization.  SO NICE!   Very nice story and voice acting...but does tend (for me) to feel like just one task after another, but THATS the game and means MORE XP!   Im not one for flashy combat like in Final Fantasy series, but Reckoning has a fast paced combat tied with awesome cinematics that will surely keep your blood flowing.  Breaking down the 3 core rpg classes into warrior, rogue, and mage...you are able to focus on one or multiclass into any combination...and you get bonuses based on your choosing which can change as you do.  The addition to a 'power up' state called 'reckoning' is awesome.  Once you build this charge you truly do feel like a bada$$ and enemies beware!    FUN FUN FUN....going to play it right now...cya!BUY THIS GAME WHILE STILL ON SALE!    or not....either way its worth getting!!!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 7, 2014
												I went into this game after being very frustrated by aspects of Divinity 2. Kingdoms of Amalur turned out to be a far more satisfying experience, albeit in unexpected ways.A major selling point is that it was written by R.A. Salvatore, one of my favourite authors. However, the game's story is very forgettable. I mean that literally - I've played 60 hours, am nearly at the end, and can barely remember anything that's happened. There is a great set piece battle and a few clever side quests, but the rest just blurs together - something something "fate", something something "mortal". There's few choices and little reason to even read the dialogue most of the time - just follow the quest markers and do what the pop-up text tells you to do.What it really gets right is the gameplay. Combat is varied enough to keep things interesting, despite making up the bulk of the gameplay. Enemies flail around when set on fire, dodge arrows, resist some forms of damage and have some neat skills and spells. The player character can be built in several different ways , and the paths are distinct enough to encourage re-specing (which is quite easy to do). Controls are straightforward, although the camera can be bothersome at times.The inability to jump, with the resulting unpassable ankle-high obstacles, is irritating at first, but moving around the world is simple enough through a generous fast-travel system, and there's plenty to do as you walk around.There's no shortage of loot, both from enemy drops and in numerous chests and hidden locations. The inventory fills up annoyingly quickly, with no option to screen items by quality, but there's no shortage of merchants around.The crafting system is great, allowing all sorts of equipment, potions and gems to be made.The game loads quickly, and looks lovely even on a mid-range system.There's certainly plenty of gameplay - expect 60 or more hours to complete most of the sidequests.It's a shame the game will never be followed up, because there is an excellent core game here.

content:
er 20, 2014
												KoA: TR is a classic action / RPG in the style of Dungeon Seige III.  As such, its appeal is mostly for fans of the console based RPG who enjoy the simplistic interface and sophisticated button mashing combat.  I come strictly from the PC world so I tend to prefer things like Skyrim, Baldur's Gate, and the like.  However this game managed to keep my attention because of its "charm" and great combat.I assume that you are familiar with the basics of an ARPG title, so I'll skip right to the pros:> The world is absolutely huge.  I have 40 hours logged so far and have completed about half the game in terms of exploring the map.> The number of quests and side quests is equally enormous.  Given this, the means for managing them all works quite well... any quest can be designated "primary" and tracked easily through the kingdom.  Secondary quests appear only on the detailed map which shows the immediate area.> The voice acting is excellent, and ALL NPC dialog is spoken.  I recognized one of the voice actors from Skyrim!  I wouldn't be surprised if there are others from the school of Bethesda.>  The combat, which is the meat and potatoes of the game really, is fantastic.  This is the primary reason to play this game.  The controls are easy to learn (I recommend an XBOX controller) and the unlocks as you progress are interesting and powerful.> Although there are basic classes (ranged/mage/tank) the level of customization available allows you to combine classes in interesting ways or focus on a specific branch within the class.> Crafting is available (create gems/blacksmithing/alchemy)... and exploring any one of those paths yeilds GREAT rewards mid-late game.> The pacing is excellent, and largely under your control.> AWESOME support for 3D Vision... you will want to patch the game using helixmods.  Google it.> Great weapon effects, such as flame, electricity, ice etc.> The story is interesting.> The camera is generally well managed by the game, particularly in combat.> It is possible to completely "respec" your character at any time!And the CONS:> Graphically the game reminds me of world of warcraft... rather cartoonish.  Not necessarily a deal killer but I prefer a more realistic look.> The character animations are limited, in particular when speaking dialog.  You will see the same animations repeated hundreds of times, to the point where you begin to notice them... a bit distracting.> Occasionally there are some wild camera glitches.> The difficulty can be uneven, especially early in the game.  You will be sailing along beating up baddies with abandon and then be unable to complete a boss fight without reducing the difficulty.  That seems to be less of a problem by mid-game if you have been managing your build well.> The loot drops are generally not that interesting... mostly junk, at least by mid-game... although by that time you have a specific build in mind and you are looking for specific loot.  I find that merchants are a better source of loot than drops.Overall I heartily recommend this game9/10 (if you have 3d Vision, 10/10)

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 28, 2014
												Recommend -- with caveats. There is a lot to like about this game if your interests lean towards story-heavy rpgs. The world building is generally interesting (and in parts very good), the dialogue pretty solid (and sometimes very good), the main plot line and dlcs are engaging. If you enjoy supplying an internal monologue about your character's motivations and history (e.g. playing the dlc after completing the main quest) this game allows you the space to do that. It's also pleasant to look at, though its paper doll options could be better. Downsides (especially for those interested in story-heavy rpgs): overall, the game has weak ties to other characters. There are no romances or friendships that you can build up outside of quest lines – mostly this left me feeling less-than-fulfilled from a story telling point of view, occasionally left me feeling eye-rollingly awash in cynicism, and sometimes surprised me by how much I came to care for an NPC nonetheless. The voice acting is very much a mixed bag, as are the lorestones (in game archeological audio books). Sometimes they're interesting, rarely affecting, and occasionally, I regretted touching them, because I felt bad for the people involved. The pronunciation in the game is often downright terrible. With the names, I could almost convince myself that the pronunciation changes were deliberate – e.g. the name “Ciara” pronounced as see-ah-ra rather than key-ra, but then, at other points it was just ordinary words that got mangled. Not a big deal for a lot of players of course – but for me, it was more than enough to throw me out of the story and the story was what I came for. Another issue – much of the game is heavily derivative. This is not something I have a big problem with generally, but it's worth mentioning here because of two things: one – it *felt* derivative; it wasn't something I noticed later, but rather as I was playing it, it felt like a retread of other games; two – I found myself thinking in places, “wow that's really interesting, I've never seen that before” and then immediately wondering if it's just because I'd missed the game where someone else had done it first. Again, not an issue for everybody. Someone else can probably talk about visual issues/bugs better than I can, but I would mention two things: post-processing didn't work for me (and if I hadn't worked out the problem in the demo version I probably would not have played the game at all), and some weird design decision during a major main-plot boss fight required me to look up a walkthrough because although I wasn't losing, I couldn't win. My victory was pointless and tedious and in the end I was just glad to get it over with. If I hadn't had dlc left to play, it might well have soured the memory of the game for me. BUT: overall, yes, I would recommend, and I would recommend going in with your eyes open so that you can enjoy all the things the game does well while accepting that parts of it are not fulfilling and some of it is actively frustrating. One final note: it has low to non-existent replay value for me (and I'm generally all about the replays), but I did get about 100 hours out of it between the main quest, faction quests and dlcs.

content:
22, 2012
												It's big. Too big even. After about 40 hours of questing I got tired of doing practically the same quests over and over again. I even skipped through the conversations, and I normally read/listen all dialogues, mind you. KoA is basically a MMO game in single-player form. Is it a bad game ? Not by any means. It's just that it loses focus about halfway through, giving you too many quests to deal with. This game can easily take 100+ hours to complete.The active combat system works great; you're not just pushing buttons and waiting for your character to finish off an enemy. YOU do the actual combat. It's fresh until you have unlocked most of your skills though, then it can grow a bit stale.My biggest gripe with the game was the inventory system, which was awkward to use. Having to pause, select a category and (un)equip items that way is cumbersome and frustrating. It's an area that could definitely use some work.For an action RPG it's pretty cool, but don't expect another Skyrim.[Rating: 84/100]

ry 4, 2014
												If you've heard of this game you may have heard that it is like an MMO.Don't walk away just yet. I'm not an MMO player, but I do enjoy this game.It is like an MMO in some respects, but it lacks the things that make MMOs not fun. For one thing, it isn't grindy. You don't have to invest many hours to get into this game. There are a lot of side quests, but they don't feel as trivial as the ones you might encounter in MMOs. The battle system feels very fluid and polished and you don't have to spam your number keys to get attacks off. As far as what I kind of don't like about this game there is a rather large land to explore, but it consists of a lot of trails and forks in those trails. There are some open areas, but you will mostly find yourself on trails. It isn't a real big negative though because you don't feel like the game is a linear excursion.All in all, this game is worth a look, but especially so if you can get it on a sale.

												Pretty good, but lacks its own identity (feels like Everquest + Fable, and a dozen other rpgs at once), and suffers from a lot of what makes modern RPGs (even many FPS) suck; being artificially extended with pointless busywork. 90% Sidequests for Deliver this to-, Kill 8 of-,.. "Hey you're supposed to be a warrior on an important mission to save the world, but can you go fetch my <mundane object>?"It's certainly not this game's fault. They ALL do that these days because it's an incredibly easy way to flesh out a game. Leveling via uninpired fetch quests isn't so bad in an MMORPG, but its dull as hell in single player games. I'm not anti-sidequest by any means, its just that they're a whole lot more common and less creative than they used to be.I'd still recommend it for the $5 I paid, though its ~82 metascore feels a bit high. I'd have it closer to 70.

content:
y 31, 2014
												Very enjoyable action RPG.The great freedom as to what your character will be (You can just mix all the classes in game, respec and start over anytime), what weapons or spells will you use, what stats will you hone - combined with the oddly satisfying combat (Never was a huge hammer so much fun in a game) and the "bullet time" mechanics makes it all very appealing and rarely boring, since you can just whip up completely new character with different fighting style on the spot.The huge world and story is nice. Nothing that will shock you, but you can feel the certain quality that comes with a good writer.On the downside, this game has a terrible FOV, depending on your monitor, you may end up just having your characters back over half of the screen - luckily there is an easy and fast fix called Widescreen Fixer (little program that allows you to set up your FOV and distance of the camera from your character). Another possible downer might be the very MMO-ish style of the quests and progression. You may like or dislike that, comes to personal preferences.Neutral - The game is very long. I mean it. Very long. You will likely never finish it, unless you like it as it can very easily take 100-200 hours. For me that is a plus, but I do understand some people don't fancy games of that length. You've been warned.All in all, I do absolutely recommend this game and think it's a great shame the studio is no more as they could've made something even cooler in the future.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 12, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning delivers exactly what it promises: an awesome fantasy RPG, with visceral, intuitive gameplay that is easy to pick up, wildly flexible and just plain fun, in a way that had previously not been seen in the genre. many people compare it to action games, but it's really more like an updated 3D variation of a Seiken Densetsu / Secret of Mana game. it's an action RPG with exploration, but no real platforming elements, such as no jumping. Lots of neat weapons skills, talents, spells, and combat styles to try out, and a big loot system on top of it that the Mana series only wished it had.{A General note. I pre-ordered this game when it first came out and thus played it on Origin, where I still have a copy owned.  I have three full playthroughs there each with over 130+ hours played, and one has mastercrafted equipment that made me literally invincible [unless I was afflicted with Bleed status]. And a forth playthrough done "fast" with over seventy hours on it. So my time played stats here on steam should be added to those for Origin playtime of an additional 450+ hours.}The world is accessible and vast, offering genre fans plenty to sink their teeth into. One gets the sense that they are watching an entire world unfold before them, one rich with history and lore and life. Amalur opens itself up to the player in a way that is both familiar and refreshing, then empowers the player to do incredible things. It is important to note that much of the setting lore is in books and scrolls found along the way in the various nooks and crannies of the game world, and discerned from NPC conversations, rather than thrown at you in raw exposition, except for a few areas early on, during, and near the end of the main plot line.Amalur looks, plays, and feels like a Secret of Mana / Seiken Densetsu game loaded with combos, super powers, and general badass attitude. Usability and player satisfaction were clearly at the heart of the vision for this game, and it shows. Even without a proper targeting system, your avatar quickly shifts between multiple enemies, flinging all sorts of death dealing nastiness around the battlefield. You never feel weak or hindered in combat. Enemies fall to your reaping as you deal a hurricane of destruction, be you an acrobatic Dervish, stoic solid Warrior, or serene Mage.The flexibility of the battle system is truly remarkable. You have access to three talent trees based on your standard warrior, rogue, and mage archetypes, and you assign talent points provided you meet the requirement for each allocation. This allows you to make a straight mage, a fast archer or stealthy stabber, a rough brawler, or any combination in between. The developers even encourage these types of cross-class creations, as statistical bonuses for your potential Hybrid Death-Dealer have already been planned out. Trust me, you can play Amalur any way you want. Better still, re-specing your hero requires only a small investment that is a chunk of resources early on in the game, but gets easier to bear (despite it's escalating cost) as you level up and gather more cash.Then there's the loot. Sweet Lord, is there a lot of loot! Reckoning plays quite similar to Diablo in many ways. You can scour the countryside and find a staff that easily outclasses your current weapon of choice. Maybe you find a turban that gives a massive boost to your mana pool, or perhaps a shield with a substantial bonus to your health regeneration. The character progression and loot acquisition is enough to keep you playing, and that's something I can't really say about a lot of games out there today. In essence, Amalur serves the purpose of providing you with ways to make your virtual death machine as powerful as possible.Mechanically, Reckoning stands above most current RPG releases in interface and reliability. The menus may appear dull to some eyes, but they are easily read and quickly accessed. A junk button for loot allows you to quickly sift through armaments without any hassle, and this needs to be standard in every game, period!The PC version isn't exactly optimized for the mouse and keyboard format however. I suggest using a controller if you have one because Reckoning was clearly designed for the consoles. Still, the game looks remarkably better even on a modest machine. Seeing the world run at 60 FPS certainly helps with the slightly cartoony graphics. 38 Studios and Big Huge Games have created a world worth saving, and they have given us some pretty damn cool tools with which to get the job done.[Updating my review, edited for clarity.]

ry 11, 2012
												My first impressions of Kingdoms of Amalur, if you're into RPG's get this now, don't wait until it's   on sale.  I played the demo when it was available and on the basis of that pre-purchased the  full version.  I am not disappointed.  It's not Skyrim, but it's got it's own charm, and  in some ways I'm enjoying playing this  as much as Skyrim. Some of the characters look cartoon like, but   the environments are beautifully rendered; not  in a realistic way, but with saturated colors which give the  game another worldly look .  The fighting in my opinion looks better than in Skyrim, with sword fights   similar to Prince of Persia or The Witcher.  The game is played in third person  but that doesn't detract from the game in any way, however I would have liked to have had a choice as sometimes first person is cool and at other times third person.  Overall I would say anyone into dungeon type  RPG's  will love this gorgeous looking game.  There's already DLC available for this game.

content:
6, 2014
												Try this game if you really like action RPGs, but if you're looking for a good, solid sandbox adventure, keep on walking.The game world is huge, and I mean HUGE, but a ton of it is padding, and with the limited mobility options you're given, it gets really really tedious carting your sorry carcass all over creation to get things done. After a certain point it becomes a series of well-choreographed and engaging battles held together by drudgery and vast amounts of running, and that's even with fast travel as a possibility.This game was originally envisioned as an MMO, and it really shows. You can't jump on your own, you can't really wander off the beaten path (largely because every path is so thoroughly beaten already) and without a horse or some form of mount you're left to running or sprinting. Calling this game a "wide-open adventure" is kind of like calling a hike through redwoods with the inability to look up a "wide-open adventure;" all of the things are there, but you can't really utilize them to their fullest capacity.At the end of the day, KOA:R feels exactly like what it is: a U-turn into marketability.

content:
27, 2014
												A grossly underrated, overdeveloped game. It may have cost the taxpayers of Rhode Island a fortune to make, and it may have cost Curt Schilling a lot of credibility, but the result was actually decent, even if it missed the exceeding high mark 38 studios had set for itself.In many ways, it plays and feels like a Skyrim clone, and while the comparison is fair, it's not the whole story. The combat is much closer to Darksiders than anything, and gameplay is rich enough to give completionists plenty to do. It's only serious drawback is its lack of difficulty, which can be corrected using a widely-available mod.This is most certainly one of those big titles worth pick up when you see it on sale for $5.

content:
ry 19
												Must have game for any RPG fan. 9/10 overall. A hugely underappreciated title, even moreso than Enslaved.Damn shame what happened to this IP and developer. This is by far one of the most entertaining RPGs I've played, with loads of content, fun and deep crafting system, engaging combat, etc. etc. BHG did a really good job.Pros:-Incredibly bug-free-Fun, smooth, combat-Flexible character development with easy respec-Great storytelling all over-Truely unique world-Great crafting system-I could go on and onCons:The only complaints I have are:-No new-game plus, so replay value is limited-The complex zone level-locking mechanic, in order to get the best loot and have the most end-game loot options, you'll want to level as much as possible in each zone before moving on to the next, and plan out the order you visit zones carefully, but that will make you overpowered for some areas; if you don't care about end-game loot you can just play through as you like.

content:
ry 17
 Intro To begin off with, yes this is a very alluring title of a game. With a good backstory and gameplay to easily dive into this is really the icing on the cake of RPG games. Sitting next to Oblivion, the Gothic Series and Two worlds this game is very simular in the sense of being unheard of and tending to push people away cause it's a bit older than some other titles.Story time; I played this game back in september 2012, after its Febuary release, when it was free for playstation plus, I easily clocked over 100 hours in my first playthrough. (It's so easy to get lost in the behemoth world map or get trapped into a string of quests which could be both a bessing or a curse) The pros heavily outweigh the cons, to prove so I'll make a nifty list to point out highlights in gameplay. Pros Fast paced combat+Rewarding quests+Compelling story line+Dark Souls boss setups+Enemy variety+Weapon variety+Character builds+Weapon combos+Quality DLC (worth it imo)+Minimal grinding+Interesting lore+Aged like fine wine+Loot system+Lighting and textures+WAIFU DARK ELF Cons -Very casual, easy-Mid-game difficulty spike-Hit and run combat (large enemies mostly)-Few boss fights-CTRL C + CTRL V dungeons-Enemies equivalent to Fallout 4 bullet sponges-(Story spoiler) The end Conclusion All together this is quite the tempting offhand game for people who enjoy any major titles running along the lines of Skyrim or....Witcher... Anyways, as I was saying, to completely clarify the whole fighting thing yes the boss fights are amazing, the encounters are clever and converge well with the gameplay without leaving any gross stitch lines, speaking in retrospect that is, the large enemies like the giant tri-boob desert serpent thing (Banshaen if I recall correctly) and other colossal like relitives are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to fight since you can't stunlock them into submission and don't even get me going about those Son of Laz gangbangs and Scav gank squads it's like Threshold Bridge & Iron Keep SotFS all over again. There's so much more I can say about this game but I'm just going to end saying; all in all it's a good game to pick up and play in your freetime as you don't have to dedicate and learn it unlike a few other RPGs and JRPGs. 8/10tl;dr:Quality game to jump right into, suggest buying on sale

content:
ber 1, 2016
												Forgotten Gem.For a change, I will start my review with the verdict:Great game, a must buy for ANY RPG-Lover!Don’t compare this game with Skyrim or Diablo 3 – that would do this game great injustice.If you look for an RPG with great atmosphere, graphics, audio and hours and hours (and I mean hundreds of hours!!!) of gameplay, look no further!…And this is why…in my opinion:I will try and break down this review in a few categories:Options:Only basic options are available, such as a few sound settings, resolution and few gameplay options…that is about it….not to fancy or complicated. For some players it may be too few options, but I found it a relief that with few tweaks this game can be set to my personal liking.This game was clearly built for a gameconsole (hence the limited settings-options) and to be played with a controller (x-box or similar). It doesn’t play well with keyboard and mouse. With a controller all controls are at your fingertips, whilst with using a keyboard you have to look for the controls. Making use of a controller gives the player an easy and intuitive gameplay.Character customization:Not to many features are available, but just enough to make your own character. Different hairstyles, tattoos and jewellery (like earrings) are provided.You can build your character from scratch or use a template/prefix.With the limited options available, this will only cost you a few minutes.Of course you can also choose gender and race. I only played as a human so I will not review any races. Check the internet for that.Graphics/World:What immediately catches  the eyes, are the vivid colours used in this game.Also the lighting is superb! Neon-like plants etc. light up the landscape.The style used is somewhat cartoonish: lean and slick textures with not to many details.All graphics are in perfect balance.Combine that with a HUGE map and you already have a unique universe to make your own.This game runs very smoothly on maxed out settings on my i5 with 8gb ram and Nvidia 710m laptop.Gameplay:As said before: a controller is a MUST HAVE. The game plays smoothly and relaxed.The map is huge! Sadly there are no mounts (like horses etc.) in this game, so walking is your only option, besides teleporting to locations you have already visited.One more minor issue: you cannot jump. When standing on a cliff or river/lake-side you can only jump down from certain points. Climbing up can only be done by following a predetermined route (like a slope or stairs).Items are hidden everywhere, so exploring every inch of the map is worth it….Hint: boost your “Detect hidden objects” – skill from the start….soon you will be drowning in items, which you can sell for better ones or breakdown into parts and make your own unique items (level your “blacksmith” –skill to get better parts etc.) which you can enchant with magical powers and even give a name….I called my sword “Burning Love”  …..:)Loading happens frequently but takes a very short time. It was not hindering me at all.Multiplayer is not available.Skills/Levelling:What unique is in this game: you can combine any skill with another, without messing up your character. For example: you can build a Warrior Mage (mage with sword-skills etc.) or a combined ranged- and close combat fighter in one mean fighting machine. The choice is yours!When levelling you can choose your skill and/or ability you wish to level/develop. I personally don’t like the big warhammers and VERY BIG blades, so I choose the great sword and shield path….but you can always choose other paths in the skill tree.When, for some reason, you are not happy the way your character developed, you can visit a “Fate Weaver” and COMPLETELY rebuild your character to your liking for a small fee (money is not really a problem in this game). This is quite a more than fantastic feature!Quests:I have the complete edition (so with all 2 dlc packs):Hundreds of (side) quests are available. Some short and easy, some long and more challenging.They are varied enough to make you pursue them. Also the rewards and items are worth it….only downside:  A LOT OF WALKING….and A LOT OF ITEMS….but that comes in handy for selling or crafting your own items.Hint: Complete armorsets of the same type provide bonuses. At its release this game was overshadowed by the launch of Skyrim and shortly after that, Diablo 3.But it does not deserve to go unnoticed! It is a game that deserves a big hand of applause and lots of participating gamers.

content:
7, 2016
												I have so much to say about Kingdoms! This is one of my all time favorite RPG games. The battles can be a bit repetative and you can count on your enemy throwing the same fight combo at you time and time again (which makes it pretty easy to get those parry achievements) The story line is huge! and there is so much to do in this game which brings me to my first complaint... the level cap :( You can reach the level cap by just doing the main factions. The first time i beat the main story line i was a little bummed to learn of the level cap. I mean who doesnt like to watch their XP sky rocket when you finally beat that main pain in the a** boss?! However, i just started a new game, leveled up the weapons i knew i loved and kept on going. Sometimes the camera view got a bit wonky, its hard to fight when the camera decides to view only the ground lol but it is possible. Just a slight annoyance. The open world is also huge! There are tons of side quests to keep you busy for quite awhile. I love the Fast Travel option, which lets be honest, who doesnt just love spending half the game walking from end of the map to other?! (insert sarcastic gaze) Fast Travel really really helps with a map that is this big. I downloaded The Teeth of Narcos DLC after i beat the game the first time. It's okay.... The underground sewer is a bit of a maze and isnt as "open" as the main game map, but it's still pretty fun. Again, it brings up the level cap that sucks....The game says Partial Controller Support but after 200 somthing hours i would have to say that its pretty much full controller. Has anyone heard of a Kingdoms 2?

er 10, 2014
												Would I recommend this game?THAT'S A BIG YES, thumbs up!The graphics: 10/10The story: 10/10Side quests: 8/10DLC: 9/10The story is awesome. No words for that!For the sidequests: I am talking about EVERY FREAKIN' SIDE QUEST THERE IS IN THIS GAME: there are A LOT! Some quest are big, you can earn houses for them. Some are small, get this - bring it to me - you get money, kill him - tell me he's dead - you get money. Still, they send you to beautiful places and each sidequest has is own little story and that can be really fun too, right? This game makes you feel like a God! For the DLC: buy them except for the Weapons & Armor Bundle. They'll be good in the begin of the game, somewhat in the middle of the game you will find better and stronger armor and weapons.I don't think it's worth the €4,99The Legend of Dead Kel includes a brand new quest line, multiple side quests, three Twists of Fate, previously unseen armor and weapons, and a new player home. Teeth of Naros opens up a new unique quest line, a new floating city to explore, and multitudes of unlockables. Skyrim was my favorite game before I started my adventure in Kingdoms of Amalur. This became my favorite game and it still is! I hope this review was helpful! Have a nice day! :)

content:
er 28, 2014
												This game made me feel like a kid again.I've played a ton of games to the point where I felt like nothing was new, but this is defintely a unique game.It's graphics look pretty good for it's time. It's got more of a fantasy look than anything and they certainly did a good job on that. While in combat everything looks really smooth and it's fun to look at... especially those finishers, oh man. Sometimes the combat is a little clunky though, mostly regarding the camera. It doesn't have a lock on feature so sometimes it's a little frustrating when you're trying to lock target onto someone else. With that aside, the combat is still great.Usually with an RPG, you'll have to go down a specific specialization to be powerful. That mostly holds true in this game, though you can still spread your talents more thin and still not do underwhelming damage. There's lots and lots and lots of quests. You might not even find all of them which makes this game great. Though it's no Elder Scrolls size, it's still a large game. Because you can make so many different characters and take different quest paths, it's definitely got great replay value. I'd certainly reccomend this game.9/10

30, 2016
												Very fun game. It's basically a tad bit more linear than Skyrim but also far more colerful, fantasy looking and the abilities/combat have more oomph or excitement to them. You can combo attacks and such. There is a problem with some auto targetting as aspect, but that is partly coming from somebody used to and with a preference to TES:Skyrim attack aiming. The combat is super fun, an intriguing story, cool enemies with absolutely well done themes and music. I was VERY SAD when the company tanked from bad management of funds when making the MMO version of this game: It was my most anticipated MMO in my life, based on the gameplay of this game in single player- I hope that says a lot, at least as to what I wanted to see in the MMO world when it comes to gameplay and design mechanics. So much to do, interesting weapons and cool abilities/skill trees. CON:It has some bugs and at times the UI comes as rough or not intuitive, that is a bit limited. Literally it has a number of design similarities to Skyrim, as some people that worked on it worked on this game and you can tell. IT has the UI flaws without offering the huge mod culture Skyrim did. That is the main CON to this game.My hard drive crashed when I was many hours into it so I stopped playing for a long while waiting for a good time to jump back in

content:
ry 19
												Let me start this review by saying that I had always seen this game in stores, and passed over it due to just simply not knowing much about the game or the developers. I never looked at gameplay, or even images of the game. I simply gave it no second thoughts. I figured it was another dime-a-dozen adventure game that would be thrown into the void of time and forgotten. Then, I saw the game on sale, and I made the best choice I've made in a long time. I purchased this gem and all the DLC for $9.99KOA: Reckoning is EXACTLY what I always wished Fable would have been. It's a HUGE open world adventure game with awesome loot, tons of quests, simple yet diverse combat (camera being the exception), and very smooth framerate even on the highest settings (The computer I downloaded this on only has an Nvidia GTX 750 :/ ). Anyway, I would highly recommend this game to ANYONE who used to play Fable, and wished for more. Kingdoms delivers on all fronts, and I can't believe I didn't buy this earlier. It's an absolute STEAL for the price.I won't go into an expansive list of pros and cons because you can find countless reviews prior to this one listing all of them. I'll just say that no game is perfect, but it's the amount of fun you have with it which really speaks to a game's quality. I can easily see myself investing 100+hours into this game without even blinking an eye, specially since there's the might/stealth/magic skill trees you can specialize in, making playing through a second or third time a very real possibility.

content:
y 9
												Beautifull game that never really got the attention it deserved. Cool looking area`s with a good variaty of enemy`s and large amount of quests to keep you busy. Combined with a very interesting combat system and leveling-up skills that lets you choose between various different playstyles that you can always change whenever you want to (Gold cost goes up after each reset but not too much). Simply a nice world too explore without it making you feel lost like skyrim does. However the game does have a few issues that you need to be aware of. First is saving, there is no autosave, so be sure to save often since you don`t want to lose your progress when it crashes (happened 3 times in 20 hours so its not that bad).Secondly, some quests have weird bugs wich lets you not complete them if you do things in the "wrong" order. Most of the times it`s resolved by selling the quest item and then buy it back, but sometimes it just bugs out. There are Forums out there wich can resolve many of these issues, but know that the game has it`s flaws.And thirdly the FOV of this game is very low, but with the program widescreen fixer you can alter it to your own desire, so It`s not as big of an issue but again is an inconvenience that you should know about before buying.All in all a very attractive game you can sink a lot of time in, and definitely a game you should buy or try, as it has a demo.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2016
												A gem that I find myself always coming back to. Not a perfect game, but just does so many things well you can't help but want to try every race and class. Pros: Decent graphics. Not breathtaking, but not a lot of buggy nonsense everywhere either.Story is genuinely interesting, and each DLC story makes you yearn to discover more as well.Combat. Holy cow, the combat is fun. There may only be a handful of weapon types, but the way your talents affect them and the combos you can string together is just plain fun. Mixing and matching magic spells with weapons adds some nice flavor as well.There is a LOT to do in this game. Even if you only did the main story it takes a while to finish, but rising through the ranks in the various factions is some of the best parts of the game!Your character's abilites are NEVER set in stone. You can reset everything to try new ability combos at any point in the game.Cons:This game can be very unforgiving. Probably my biggest gripe with this game, is that there is very limited auto-saving, yet many ambushes/surprise events that you can be quite unprepared for. I ragequit many a time after having hours of work sucked away by carelessly forgetting to save, then dying.The voice acting may seem decent at first, but some of the accents and voices get VERY annoying and repetitive. Not the end of the world, but definitely noticeable.At points this game can be grindy, when the level gap between zones is a little too big. One moment you'll feel like a badass, then move to the next zone and get wasted immediately(Then lose a ton of time as previously stated haha sob).Overall, 8.5 / 10I'll take slightly flawed, lesser known game with insane replay value over a big name blockbuster that leaves me yawning after 20 hours anyday.PS- Bought this on Steam after logging 100+ hours into the PS3 version. Cheers everyone!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 8, 2013
												Se você pensa em que esse jogo está abaixo das expectativas, com toda certeza você está enganado. Eu fui assim em relação a ele, até joga-lo. E mudei totalmente meu ver, é um daqueles jogos que são pouco divulgados, mas merecem o reconhecimento.O jogo se passa no Reino de Amalur, onde você é um escolhido do '' Destino '', algo que torna as coisas ao redor mudarem, e você é o principal protagonista de um certo experimento ter dado certo e escolhido para impedir o mal ( Clichê que nunca acaba. )Mas, vendo ao mundo vasto que Amalur mostra, sidequests são quase infinitas, dungeons são várias e os cenários,  super bem feitos e diferenciados.Eu já vi isso em vários outros jogos, mas de qualquer forma vale ressaltar o elemento mais ♥♥♥♥ que KoA abrange:  o Combate Hack N' Slash.Não é como em RPGs clássicos que você '' de repente '' encontra um inimigo, ou em uma batalha em turnos, é tudo naquele momento, você viu o inimigo e ja começa a pancadaria, independente do ambiente que for, todos os movimentos acontecem e fluem extremamente bem, sem um único erro ou bug. E até com 4 inimigos a sua frente, é possível enfrentá-los todos ao mesmo tempo, focando todos ao modo que você quiser, através de ataques corpo-a-corpo, longo alcance e magia.Isso já determina as 3 classes, que, apesar de serem poucas, possuem habilidades significativas para cada uma das classes.Exemplo: Não é possível ser Mago do Fogo ou do Gelo, Mago é Mago, você usatanto fogo, como gelo, eletricidade, e até sumona um esqueleto para lhe ajudar.Um fator legal das classes é você poder misturar uma com a outra, podendo fazer um guerreiro + mago, ou assassino + guerreiro, e por ai vai.Mas claro, é possível seguir uma skill tree só, mas eu acho meio chato sinceramente, já que o jogo oferece você poder misturar os combos de cada classe para acabar com os inimigos.O level máximo do jogo é 40, achei baixo, mas é o suficiente para você poder aprender todas as skills da '' árvore '' da sua classe.A quantidade em termos de itens são poucas, porém há muitas variações de um mesmo item, incluindo raros,lendários e os sets ( que fazem parte de um combo de equipamentos ).No jogo também são incluídas facções, que é possível se juntar,assim obtendo mais sidequests e seguir a mainquest dessas facções, são ao total 7 facções no jogo. Descubra por si mesmo auhauhauHá também as cartas, que são obtidas de várias maneiras, e oferecem ao jogador bônus exclusivos, como maior dano, regeneração de vida, e por ai vai.Dentro desse esquema existem também as lorestones, que contam poesias e poemas sobre Amalur, achando um set completo de lorestones, você ganha bônus para algo específico também,Falei muito bem dele até agora, mas KoA contém seus pontos negativos também.Um deles é o Summon da skill de Mago, que aparentemente não fica maior ou mais parrudo quanto mais ele upa, ele aprende novos combos para abater os inimigos. Achei diferente, porém estou acostumado com os summons parrudos do Diablo II, auahuahuah.Outra coisa são os personagens, todos são muito bonitinhos, coloridos, mas isso é o estilo do jogo mesmo, mas é impossível você ficar horrendo no jogo, é mais fácil ficar com uma aparência bizonha e estranha.Além disso, tem certos NPCs extremamente fracos em relação a personalidade, uns 70% do jogo, então não espere muito deles. Claro que tem alguns que te acompanham pelo resto do jogo, que obviamente vão estar bem melhores que os outros.Não há companions permanentes, só temporários.BUGS malignos, como som atrasado, acontecem algumas vezes, ou também o jogo fica mudo, mas volta ao normal.FInalizando, KoA é um daqueles RPGs que você com certeza não bota fé por não seguir os estilos clássicos como FF, Tactics Ogre, Diablo II, ES,etc.Mas, mostra por um lado, uma obra prima que conseguiu colocar o combate como maior foco do jogo, coisa que poucos não focam e muitos gostariam de ver a ação tomar '' ao vivo '', um mundo incrível para explorar, itens para achar e melhorar e seu personagem, e principalmente, um caminho a escolher para o seu Destino.8/10.

content:
ry 22, 2014
													I purchased Kingdoms of Amalur on Steam as a complete package for $11.99 which included all of the DLC and finished the main story in 53 hours.  As with most games I play, I finished all the side quests I came across. Graphics – Great	I loved the graphics in KOA.  There is a strong a vivid use of color and the world is filled with detail.  Animations are fluid and my PC never once stuttered the frame rate from a constant 60 fps.  The environments could have used a little more variety as by endgame you will grow tired of the same recycled assets. Music – Fair	The music in KOA is well orchestrated but the songs lack depth and variety.  More songs would have been a plus as a large amount of time is spent in each area before going to the next and this can have you listening to the same loop for many hours at a time. Cinematics – Good	Picture the same dialogue cutscenes as KOTOR or Mass Effect.  The dialogue itself is very well written but unlike the Mass Effect series, you may not find yourself delving into the various conversation options.  The characters and their backgrounds just weren’t interesting enough for me.  The choices during conversations also lacked the Mass Effect style feeling of autonomy.  You could make good or evil choices but it never mattered much.  “Quick Time” events in combat are a cool sight to see. Story – Good	As RPGs go, this story is original and kept me interested enough to finish the game to see what happens.  I did not grow attached to any of the side characters or find them interesting.  This game is really all about you.  The main villain(s) were menacing but far from the kind of evil we love to hate. Control – Great	I had no issues with the controls.  They are very simple and easy to learn.  The UI was easy enough to use.  The awkward camera may startle you at first but you quickly get used to it. Gameplay – Fair	I played as a melee class so your experience may vary.  Combat in the beginning is fun but quickly grows stale.  All I really had to do was click mouse 1 until everything died.  Even on the hard setting, combat becomes too easy as you gain better weapons and armor.  You completely overpower everything and I did not die once the entire game.  I also never needed any of the consumable items with the exception of a very rare healing potion. Content – Good	There is plenty to do here and the game’s zones adjust to your level so you are free to do as little or as much as you want to for side quests.  The loot you find is very rewarding in the beginning of the game but by the middle, I was scrapping everything I found for parts.  I had over five million gold with nothing to spend it on. Value – Great	For $12 I had 53 hours of fun.  The game is huge and kept me playing until I finished.  I did not feel inclined to play through the DLC quest lines.  In my opinion, they weren’t worth it. Recommended – Yes	I recommend this game for the price I paid.  In my opinion, this game is worth $20 or less.  It is currently $19.99 on Steam without the DLC.

Fun: 2/4 & Plot:4/4The good thing about this game is the avatar can be customize yet its boring, of course its fun, you can create your own character and became the character by exploring the world and experience the tale of your awesomeness, but, that's make you feels there is lack of something. There is no love, yes, i cant find anything that i can love about this avatar. Why? because there is no character to fall in love with! P/s: Also, the customerize appreance,face,and others stuff is limited. Character:1/4Skill set is awesome, you can upgrade your own power based on what type of your character, not only that, the charcter can have a multiple type of skill set and power.This mean, i can play as mage but at the same time,i can play as rogue. Yet, the weopen is limited, there is nothing fancy about them, just a typical weopen that can been seen on others game. Skill&Inventory: 3/4Overall, there is nothing much to talk about, this is a good game, if you are a player that like to play a game like diablo, torchlight, or any common game that share the traits of RPG and pack of full blown action, this is a game for you( while waiting new game to get realease). Overall: 3/5
