content:
2014
												KoA:R was a surprise buy for me while I was trying to take a break from binging on Dota 2. Didn't touch it for a few weeks before deciding I would dust it off.I honestly should have started playing this sooner.One design aspect I really enjoyed when starting off is how easily I was able to distract myself early in the game regarding combat and character development. Normally in these types of open RPGs, I tend to get bored early on and rarely get to the part of the game where you actually feel badass and know what you're doing: you have good gear, nice weapons you're glad to have found, some money in the bank, etc. KoA:R lets you play around enough early on with different playstyles so that by the time you find the playstyle that fits you best, you are already well-geared and feel like a power house.Combat is fluid, the weapons are overall pretty great (although I wish I had more patience for the slower weapons in the game e.g. Greatsword, Hammer, etc.).There are likely flaws to this game that I haven't mentioned, but currently, I haven't really found anything that would annoy me enough to stop playing mid-session.PRO-TIP: Play on hard mode!! I started off on Hard and was wondering why some of the enemies were still so easy. This changes as your progress and find new mobs to fight, and luckily this is around the time where you are able to grasp how to hold your own.9/10 Still playing, and will likely reroll a character after I finish on this guy!

content:
27, 2014
												I'm hesitant to recommend this game because I didn't love it, but for some reason I kept playing it until the end.  I found myself speeding through some of the more boring bits of the game just to see the main storyline through to completion, but honestly, the main story leaves much to be desired.  The world is huge and feels very complete, but unfortunately much of this is lost if you--like me--can't quite cross the threshold into obsession with exploring the world.The gameplay is fairly fun and varied for an action RPG, but the skill progression for the sorcery tree is VERY unbalanced.  You'll spend the first third of the game abusing the same couple of abilities over and over again, feeling somewhat underpowered and dependent on your physical weapon to fill in the damage gaps.  It starts to balance out a bit in the middle of the sorcery tree, but then the scales are tipped ridiculously upon reaching the highest tier.  The Meteor ability is capable of wiping out an entire group of enemies, and while it does have a long cooldown, it is always ready by the time you reach the next group and doesn't consume enough mana to slow you down.  Speaking of mana, itemization was a bit frustrating and seemed too random.  I finished the game with a staff bought from a vendor, but then again, I was just destroying armies of fools with giant meteors summoned from the depths of space, so who needs a nice staff?One of the things that continued to irritate me in this game is the sound.  I'm not sure if they didn't have the budget for a good sound team or if they hired amateurs, but the sounds in this game feel completely wrong.  One example is the sound they used for a shattering clay jar.  It doesn't feel like part of the environment, but instead a flat sound file played slightly out of sync with the action.  There are many other examples of terrible sounds throughout the game.  The music was occasionally decent, but for the most part it was forgettable.The graphics in this game were nice enough, and the art style felt consistent and well-done.  Framerate was never an issue on my aging machine--even with settings on max--so clearly the core tech team behind the engine knew what they were doing.All of my complaints aside, I still found myself coming back to this game day after day to see what was around the next bend.  Upon completion, I almost felt as if I could do more exploring or wrap up some of those faction quests I left unfinished...but, I have better games to play.  If you like MMO-style gameplay and want to get lost in a big, lonely world for hours on end, give Kingdoms of Amalur a shot.  However, if you--like me--find yourself with less and less time to play games these days, you may not get as much out of this game as you put into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
16, 2014
												This game is:An rpgThat plays like Dragon Age: OriginsThat also plays like an MMOWith the combat style of Dragon Age: 2.I'll explain. If you've ever played an MMO before, you'll know that there's a rotation to your skills/abilities. This game offers up three sorts of abilities - melee, ranged, and magic. The game allows you cross-abilities and encourages it. The UI is set up like a typical MMO sort. The controls aren't difficult to grasp.You move as though you were in an action game. Think Kingdom Hearts if you've ever played that. Or Devil May Cry.This game came out about the same time as Skyrim. It was overlooked because of this, and subsequently the developers went out of business.This is a tragedy. The game has the same open world feel as Skyrim, and allows you to fast travel to places you've been before. The looting system is much the same, only it allows for more.For instance, you get the inventory is full instead of slowing down.For another, within your inventory are bags. Each bag is for a crafting. Alchemy, sagecrafting (jewelcrafting), and blacksmithing. The components for all are placed within these bags, and not in your actual inventory. So you can stock up as much as you like on them all.You're able to purchase a house, expand it, and have your own shared storage within it.The scenery is gorgeous, the characters are pretty amusing, and while the character customization is sparse, you're allowed to be something other than friggin' human.The plot has an absolutely fascinating premise, and how many games can you play that starts you off in a dumping ground for corpses?It also touches a LOT on fae mythology. Brownies, trolls, sprites, etc. The elves are particularly badass in this game rather than being a bunch of pretentious snots or a downtrodden race.The downside to this game is that there won't be any sequels coming to it due to the company going out of business.

content:
3, 2014
												This game surprised me.  I read some reveiws that said it was surprisingly good but it still caught me off guard.  I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I am.  It's a pleasant feeling to be surprised these days by a game that seemed to be so resoundingly denounced on release.  I highly recommend playing it, even with all its' flaws, because it's fun and familiar. Let's get the bad out of the way:-The first 30 minutes.  It's awkward to control without tweaking because it was absolutely designed to be used with a controller.  If you have one, I recommend using it.  If not, tinker with sensitivity and hotkeys to make it more playable.  The defacto tutorial level is unimpressive, slightly confusing, and rather buggy.  It takes you through each class and weapon type but you don't have to commit just yet.  At this point it seems to be super linear, on rails type of game but push through to the first village and it opens up.-The camera.  It takes getting used to.  The third person perspective is unfortunate.  While I generally play in third person, not having the option to move the camera is frustrating at times.  This is one of the areas where it's design for consoles is very evident.-Vanilla.  This isn't really a negative or a positive.  It's what you expect from a game like this.  Some fetch quests, some kill quests, some steal quests, a few factions and schools to join, and the RPG trinity of classes.  Even with some multiclassing, it's still an expected experience class wise.The Good:-Rich lore.  If you didn't know, it is written by RA Salvatore and it shows.  Some of the stories feel familiar if you are a fan of his books.  One of the first questlines, The House of Ballads, is very interesting and they continue in the vein throughout.-Tons of side quests.  You can get lost in sidequests for a few hours with each new area and those discovered in the wild.-Combat seems simple on the surface (and can remain so if you desire) but with multiclassing can become dynamic and engaging.-Crafting! I generally only craft because I have to but this system makes it easy.  It is not particularly deep or impressive in it's installation but it is perfect for players like me who don't generally dump a ton of time into it.  I like that you can craft usable items at any point no matter the skill level.  Strength of weapons or armor are based on components used and NOT player skill.  A small but important distiction.This game is everything you expect from an open world RPG in the Elder Scrolls vein.  Why would that be a bad thing?  Just because it has been done before doesn't mean it can't be done again and done well.  Pick it up and have fun with it, I know I have.

content:
2, 2014
												I inititally dismissed KoA when it was released, thinking it was just another bland RPG game. However after buying it on a whim I was blown away by the amount of content. The quest system is solid and will keep you busy for the forseeable future, and the game is brilliantly optimized.As of writing this review I am not even half way through my first playthrough (finishing the main quest lines in both DLC zones). There are three distinct classes to level in depending on whether you want to be a ranger, who favours bows, a mage, who can summon powerful AoE spells, or the cheapest class I have found, the warrior. You are not limited to one class or the other and can make just about any character you could so desire. but the only way to get the very most powerful perks is to invest all of you skill points in to one skill branch.The crafting system is solid, allowing you to make your own potions, weapons and armor, as well as gems that infuse your items with other powers (Health or mana regen, poison damage, extra armor). Crafting your own gear is recommended as anything you make with high enough ingredients will out perform any weapon or armor piece found in the world.The game world itself is huge, and given that your character does not have a mount, you will be walking everywhere (fast travel becomes available after visiting a location). There are many different biomes that you will visit on your journey from lush jungles, to scorched deserts, to damp marshes.It is true that no game is perfect, and I am quite sad that the developer shut down after this game was released, my personal rating for this game is:Story 7/10     The game starts in a new way to anything I have ever seen before, but still has some cliche momentsGameplay 8/10     The fighting system is a breath of fresh air to me after skyrim, it feels fluid and quick swapping lets you juggle your opponentsGraphics 7/10     Don't expect crysis the RPG the game does look a bit cartoony but it earns the high rating because it fits so well with the gameSound 9/10     The ingame soundtrack is beautiful and the little details and subtle sounds bring this game to life, an absolute pleasure with headphonesThis has become my favourite RPG in my steam library and I cannot recommend it highly enough, the game might be a bit slow for some people to begin with but after you begin levelling up you choose the pace

												I've always felt RPGs to be a bit different than other types of games. They require time, dedication, and skill. But in return, they give you one of the greatest possible benifits- no, not a drip for your sensory systems or endorphins, but an endless creativity and a bueatiful world. That being said, creating a game is different from creating a painting. It can't just look good, it must be fun to play, fun to interact with, fun to experience. And while when many think of RPG, TES comes to mind, I think Amalur: Reckoning is one of those games that is sorely missed. It carries you into a colerfull, viberant, world, ripe with imagination and ready for the taking. It gives you what is, in my opinion, a better system than any other game- it allows you to have the freedom of skyrim, but also the classical class system and skill trees. The gameplay is fun, the world is simply gourgeous, and the lore is plentiful. This is one hell of a game you would not want to miss.(NOTE: I am a PC gamer, however, I find this game is much more enjoyable with Xbox 360 controller. Its not meant for it, but it sure should be!)

content:
0, 2014
												The RPG format is one where you have fairly clear expectations.  Despite this, most of them get it wrong.  But KOA Reckoning is the first one I've found in a long time that has actually had me telling myself I needed to go to bed (and then ignored my own advice).  The storyline is rich, which a lot of developers forget is important when you're supposed to be *playing* a role in a virtual world, and the gameplay is fun and flexible.  As much as I love games like The Witcher, the user interface and controls can be awkward and clumsy; this game overcomes those problems and is genuinely enjoyable from start to finish - where you'll actually *want* to spend dozens of hours off on lore-related side quests instead of begrudgingly doing them out of necessity.  Overall one of the best RPGs that I've ever played.  I haven't checked out the DLC yet, but it's definitely something I'll be doing and not just considering.

												An excelent game. It has a level of character customizability that rivals and possibly surpasses the Elder Scrolls series. Your ability to thoroughly customize your character's powers and abilities adds a level of forthought to who you want your character to be while you fight. If you don't like the way your stats are progressing, then you can wipe the slate clean and start over. Through the course of the story line, you could have a warrior, a mage, a rogue, a combination of any two, or all three. Plus, your ability to sneak, forge, craft potions, find hdden items and other such skills are seperate from the combat skill trees. You could have a warrior with an insanely high sneaking and discovering items skills, or a thief that likes to forge weapons and armor. Basically, this game is definately worth playing, Nine out of ten, I'd say.

												Short: The game is amazing, yet so underrated and overlooked. It's got good character customization and creation, it has a plethora of awesome weapons and delivers a funny yet dramatic storyline.* Pros- Open world (HUGE)- Lots of weapons and other equipment- Three "classes" to choose from, warrior (Might), rogue (Finesse) and mage (Sorcery) with lots of skills each, which can be mixed! (I.e. Might/Finesse or Finesse/Sorcery or a bit of everything).- The player is fateless, so you can choose different fate-cards that have different effects, choices in dialogue also make differences.- Funny dialogue, you can decide what to say and get a funny response if it's absurd.- Lots to explore, many dungeons, areas and quests!- Awesome combos and finishing moves* Cons- Lacks some sounds, even though your player says something, there's no sound for the dialogue. (Though the npc's are voiced)- There aren't as many monsters as weapons, enough, but there could be more. (Some vanilla are even used in the dlc content)- There's no mounts, so running everywhere is a pain sometimes. (There is fast-travel though)

content:
, 2014
												This game really fullfilled my action RPG needs and it's got some great features. First of all, I got a bit shaken off by the camera system, but I got used to it. It's quite funny because this game kinda has to be compared to Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, because they came out practically at the same time. I made a bit of a comparison with a friend where I called this one a "little skyrim".That said, this game has some unique features, such as:+Fate meter/Reckoning Mode (special combat mode, like an overdrive)+Twists of Fate (bonus after certain key quests)+Destinies (passives according to character stat growth you made)The game has some replay value since you can:+Do story and optional quests again giving different answers and check the other's reactions+Invest on Persuasion in order to see different reactions+Align yourself to good or evil in certain story quests where you're given the option to either kill an ancient being(or keep it imprisioned) or unleash him for his powerAs for the game design itself, some pros and cons are:Pros:+You can do Stat resets anytime by visiting a Fateweaver and paying some game currency+Fast paced combat which rewards for diversity over repetition+Varied weapons, skills and playstyles to choose and re-choose from+Big meaningful sidequests for certain factions+Skippable DRM (the game asks for your e-mail, but if you don't input it, it carries on)+Investing on different abilities (lockpicking, blacksmithing, stealth, detect hidden,...) may unlock new dialogue optionsCons:-The main storyline boss fights are quite dull-Most of times your input doesn't matter for how the NPCs' general reaction unless it's from one of those unlockable options-Once you enter a map, monsters are designed to accomodate to the level you were when you entered, forever, meaning old areas become easy pretty fast if you're "running errands"-Killing enemies while stealth doesn't alarm someone beside that guy, but killing a civilian in a city hidden in the attic brings all the cities' guards over, for some reason.Overall verdict:It has got me playing for some time and got me interested in the story and some of it's features, but it didn't become memorable and some parts of it just seemed unpolished. Your interaction with the game's world is meaningful, but only to a certain extent.

content:
, 2014
												One of my favorite games of the last generation. The story may seem nonsensical and the facial expressions of the characters may seem wooden, but it's all more than carried by the superb battle system. It is an absolute joy. One of the best non-turn based battle systems I have ever used. Easily on par with Dark/Demon Souls. It's fast paced and fluid. It just feels good. It makes you feel like an utter badass. You are given 3 archetypes to work with: Mage (clear enough), Rogue (bows, daggers, fast stuff, cool assassiny skills) and Might (great swords, hammers, tanky things). You can go solo in any tree or mix between two or even all three. Putting points in trees unlocks tarot cards as you go on that change how your character functions in fights. The 3rd tarot for a Mage/Rogue hybrid for example changes your roll dodge into a teleport and tarots beyond that adds the ability to poison enemies that you teleport through. It's pretty rad.The game world is also pretty expansive; it'll take you a long time to finish everything. Steam is for some reason saying I've only put 3 hours into the game but I know that I have bare minimum but in 40 hours (lots of airport layovers while travelling) but I'm pretty sure I'm only about halfway through the games content. Lots and lots of questing to do here. Just buy the game. It's a good time.

content:
r 11, 2014
												I'm going to compare this game to Witcher 2 and Skyrim because they are my two favourite RPGs and many people have played them. Secondly, if you're going to buy this game, it goes on sale fairly often so I would suggest waiting for a saleKoA does a lot of things right but a lot is sincerely average:KoA has the option to completely change your character's style and perks at any point meaning that you can change the type of character you have whenever you want to try something new. This is cool but it made me feel like a second playthrough would be fairly pointless as I have already tried all the character builds in one playthrough.Playing through the whole game the environments are beautiful and varied. The look of the game is more animated than Skyrim or the Witcher and this gives it a "friendlier" look, this is either good or bad depending on your preference.The fighting mechanic is fun and fairly reactive, being more like the Witcher than Skyrim. You can dodge and mix spells and abilities seamlessly in with melee or ranged combat. I found the game too easy, playing the whole thing on hard and never really struggling, eventually you become so powerful that you cannot be beaten and fighting creatures becomes tedious even though the fighting mechanic is funThe main story line is decent and has some originality but is definitely not on the level of the Witcher (but few games are in my opinion)The faction storylines are fun and to the point but fairly predictableBut the side quests have some cool little twists and original little stories.The soundtrack is terribly repetitive and NPCs like talking during battles which results in you missing half of what they are saying because the background noise is so loudSome reviewers found the voice acting sketchy but I did not notice any problemsThere is a lot of lore to be discovered which is nice for people into that and it isn't thrown in your face so you can ignore it if you wantLastly, you can sell any item to any merchant and they all have unlimited funds (because running around trying to sell things in Skyrim is pretty annoying)Pros:Beautiful environmentsGreat fighting mechanicLots of loreDecent storylineRecustomising your character at any pointCons:Too easy (for a Dark Souls person)Predictable Repetitive soundtrack and some difficulty hearing NPCs explain key story points (which they don't repeat)No point in a second playthroughSo in conclusionKoA is a fun game that I would recommend to any RPG fan, but I personally would not rank it above either Skyrim or the Witcher 2

content:
3, 2016
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning came out at a bad time. It was only about 3 months after Skyrim launched and most western RPGs now had a new king to contend with. This game fell under the radar and the studio closed even, which is unfortunate as this is a great game.Penned by R.A. Salvatore the world of Amalur is familiar enough for a traditional western RPG player but different enough in it's storytelling to be just compelling enough to keep on playing. Everything is fully voice acted and quite well at that. I personally didn't find myself falling in love with any characters in particular but the story is only one part of this game. One of the other great parts of this game (and in my opinion the main reason to pick it up and play) is the combat. The combat is fast, interesting, and requires a decent amount of strategy. The easiest game to compare it to in terms of combat is God of War. You'll be building combos, countering, and dodging your way to victory with a wide variety of weapons that almost all play differently. Fortunately you can handle two different weapon sets at a time allowing for a significant amount of customization that let's you create a character that fits your play style. Visually, the game is decent. There isn't much in the way of lush foliage like in The Witcher 3 but the color palette is vibrant and on an artistic level the game shines, even if it's not necessarily a technical marvel. Armor and weapons look especially cool even if many modern visual effects aren't present.In terms of getting all the achievements keep in mind that this is an open world RPG. This means very few missable achievements (although there are a few so check a guide beforehand) and several story related achievements. There were some kill grinds which are always fun in addition to semi-collectible achievements. I would also recommend the DLC if you don't mind forking out extra dough. If you can get them on sale even better. You'll also need them to 100% the game on Steam.Overall, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a great western RPG that unfortunately fell under the radar. It's a shame more people didn't play this game because it tells a pretty good story, has some of the best western RPG combat around, and looks pretty good from an artistic point of view. I highly recommend picking this one up especially if you consider yourself an RPG fan.8.5/10

content:
12
												PLAYTIME: 30+ hours on XBox 360. 10 on PC.I was leery of the game's notoriously easy difficulty level, so I chose to handicap myself a little. I played on the hardest difficulty level, and did not accept any HP upgrades. If the game became too easy, I would remove armor.Thankfully, the game turned out to be enjoyable enough for me to purchase the 360 and PC versions of this title.PROS[+] Very good combat. Melee and projectile attacks are mostly viable for all weapon and spell types, without being too easily abused. Some enemy mobs are dangerous enough on the highest difficuty level to require light tactical decision-making on the player's part. Dodging and cancelling your combo attacks will help you get past tougher enemies.[+] Several helpful interface features make lootgathering and questing more manageable thann games like Skyrim. Multiple waypoints can be selected via Active Quest selection. Inventory management is helped immensely by one-button junkgathering and junkselling. Gathered loot is easily compared to the gear you wear.[+] Loot model is reasonably generous.[+] Very colorful visuals with fluid animation.CONS[-] Combat only allows one or two types of attack per weapon, tops. Beyond the basic 3- or 4-hit combo and a charged attack, there are no variations to weapon attacks.[-] Combat on lower difficulty levels is too easy, since enemies are constantly stunned by your basic attacks and never really fight back. (On the highest level, stunlocks are much shorter.)[-] The early areas of the game are mostly claustrophobic: a series of caves and tree-lined corridors.[-] Maps only allow one custom waypoint. Players maybe be able to manipulate the Active Quest in order to juggle two waypoints, however.[-] Exploration is far more two-dimensional than Skyrim. Hills and mountains can only be scaled via designated points on the map. It makes the exploration less dangerous in vertical areas (since you can't die by falling), but means travel options are less common.[-] The story is mostly a forgettable jumble of lore and characters that are far from compelling.[-] Music is so subdued, it's almost nonexistent.

												I had heard that this game was too similar to an MMORPG without actually being one to be fun, but these claims were wrong. Certainly, the quest system is a degree like an MMO's, but it was nowhere near as monotonous, and I went through the game doing every quest for every region, and only became tired of that when I had went through every piece of land on the lefternmost (see: largest) continent, and was about 40 hours in. The combat is fantastic. I only played as a warrior, but the moves were so stylish, and made you feel so powerful, that I never got tired of fighting. The challenge is kept consistent all the way through, and the gameplay and character customization overshadow the admitably awful story and characters (that fortune-teller dude that follows you throughout the game is badass, though, as is your gnome buddy). I strongly recommend this. One playthrough, including DLC, will get you 50+ hours, and it is certainly replayable.

												Kingdoms of Amalur is a good Action-RPG in its own right. It has plenty of loot drops, a very action oriented battle system and a very good skill tree.The skills are fun to explore and satisfying to combine, to find your own playstyle.The quests usually range from killing X to talk to Y and fetch Z. Nothing new here. The game features a huge map, which is unfortunately not a single map, like in Skyrim, but large Zones that are connected without a loading screen. Art style and graphics are very colourful, yet gorgeous, comic-esque. And although it looks a little like Torchlight, it features rather bloddy finishing combos. If you are in need of easy action without a deep story KoA might capture you for hours, until something "better" comes along. It's not Skyrim and it does not try to be, but it's also not as mature, deep and tantalizing.

												This is one masively underrated RPG in my opinion.  A massive world full of people, factions, quests to do, places to explore and experiences to be had, it never received the due praise that it should have received.Possessing a truly original and authentic story and set in a vibrant world, I keep coming back to this game for more.  A non-linear leveling system that actually lets the player customize the game around their own playstyle, and a Fate system that allows for either further customization and giving the player a sence of accomplishment.  I wish more RPGs could be as well thought out and beautiful as this one.For a single playthrough to experience a near full clear will take well over 100 hours, and that does not even touch the DLC.  At $40, this is an RPG YOU HAVE TO TRY.  The demo includes not only the starter "tutorial area", but after that you can take to the first zone for 45 minutes and do ANYTHING you want - quests, crafting, gathering, killing NPCs, whatever your heart desires.I cannot say enough great things about this game.  I wish everyone could get as lost in a single game as I did (and still do) with Kingdoms of Amalur.

content:
17, 2014
Here's the tl;dr at the top of the post: Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is absolutely worth your time.Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is an open-world, action RPG created by the unfortunately defunct 38 Strudios. After booting the game and playing the first extended mission, you will quickly realized that a lot of love went into this game. There's not many games out there that feel like the people who made them were making a game that they simply adored and would want to play themselves. However, this is, without a doubt, one of those rare games.Let's take a look at some bullet points straight from the Steam store page:- Uncover the secrets of Amalur in hundreds of hours of immersive gameplay, from the vibrant city of Rathir to the vast region of Dalentarth to the grim dungeons of the Brigand Hall Caverns.This bullet is not exaggerating with the "hundreds of hours" bit. I've easily sunk 63 hours (as of this posting) into the game and I have no idea if I'm close to the end. And you know what? I'm fine with that. The story is engaging and the world is full of awesome locations full of interesting people eager to send you even farther out into the world.One of this game's most amazing strengths is that EVERY SINGLE QUEST has full voice acting. You never have to read a line of text if you don't want to. For me, this keeps the game interesting and pushes me to play farther into the story because I actually care about these characters. For once, the NPCs are not just cardboard cutouts with text attached to their face. It's incredible what a difference that makes.Okay so it has a ton of missions and voice acting, but does it have a world to support these characters and their stories? Hell yes it does! Take a look at this next point of interest:- Explore deep levels of lore in a universe steeped in 10,000 years of fiction created by New York Times bestselling author R.A. Salvatore.Kingdoms Of Amalur has an Elder Scrolls level of world back story. Every book you find has a story written inside them about the towns, cities, people, and invading monsters. Exploration is rewarded with notes written by local townsfolk about their everyday lives, how they came to be, and their personal demons. Some merchants even keep inventory notes that you can peak at. You can spend hours just talking to individual people in the towns and learn how they feel about certain locations, the legends of old, and events that are likely to happen.If you're one who craves lore, this game will not disappoint.Lots of missions: Check. Lots of lore: Check. How about a good combat system: Double Check:- Customize your play in a dynamic combat system that delivers some of the most intense and responsive action ever seen in an RPG.- Seamlessly integrate magical and melee attacks as you take on scores of enemies in grand fight sequences and finish them off with brutal Fateshift kills.The combat system is a hybrid of God Of War and the Fable series. You can move around feely, use two seperate weapons (of any type), and dispense of 4 different magic spells at anytime during battle. There's also a nice blocking mechanic that slows down time and knocks back any enemies around you to give you the upper hand.Combat has a very light locking mechanic as well. All the melee weapons have a 3 to 4 point combo that can be executed by pressing the button at a certain pace. Once you hit someone, the game will softly nudge you to keep you hitting the target. The reason I say "softly" is because you can change your direction at any point during an attack. See someone coming up from behind? Whip around and hit him with the final attack from your combo to make sure he doesn't get you with your back turned.Spells vary. There's a ton to choose from. Some are simple character effects, some are projectiles, while others are area of effect attacks. Each has a special visual style and devastating effects that can be upgraded through the abilities tree.The "Fateshift" mentioned in the second bullet is a slow-motion mode that is activated once your Fate meter fills up from killing enemies. When Fateshift is activated, you are given increased damage output as you kill as many enemies as you can in the allotted time and then perform a special finisher move to the final enemy. Doing so gives you extra experience points!Alright, so there's one final piece I'd like to talk about, and that's the character building:- Build the character you've always wanted with the revolutionary new Destiny system that allows you to continuously evolve your character class to your style of play.- Create and modify your hero with millions of combinations of skills, abilities, weapons and pieces of armor.When it comes to character classes, there are three main choices: Might (Warrior), Finesse (Rogue), and Sorcery (Magic). You can either fully spec one of these classes, or go for something a bit more interesting and incoperate a little of each. Doing so actually effects some of the class bonuses (called Destinies) you get later in the game.Also, if at any point during the game you get bored of your current class or you want to change your profession, visit a Fateweaver and simply respec every single skill and ability point you've earned so far for a small amount of coin. The game is long, and you'll like want to do this once or twice just to change things up and try something new. It's always nice when a game is flexible.There you have it, my extended thoughts on Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning. Hopefully through this post I've helped alleviate any doubts you may have had about the game and pushed you towards trying a wonderfully crafted RPG full of exciting characters, locations, and monsters. Good luck in Amalur!http://forums.fungineers.net/index.php?topic=1403.msg22646#msg22646

content:
ry 1, 2014
												Hands on the table, I've yet to explain such a great experience as I have been having with this game, thus far. Amalur: Reckoning, has become a favorite in a matter of moments, to me.If you are in search of a story-backed, heavily armored RPG, or something to bring an emotional (and nostalgic) rememberance to you. THIS IS IT!Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning has brought back to me the same nostalgia of games such as, Fable, Morrowind, and other timeless classics that brought in a new era of RPG gaming. 9.3/10 Story8/10 Graphics10/10 Content8/10 UI/Combat Mechanics10/10 Replay ValueThe story is unique and enthralling from my point of view as the player, many bonds formed in the game. Reckoning has an exciting amount of information to learn for almost every NPC character as well, there is lots to learn, and always a bonus! Graphics are intriguing, lots of intuitive graphic inspirations which look and feel similar to games such as WoW, Prince of Persia, Fable 2, and The Last Remnant.I could not ask for ANY more content from this game, personally. The content that has been provided, is incredible. It takes a keen eye to see all the little details put into the fabrics of this game, and there is a bountiful amount of things to do in this game, never boring. As for the UI of this game, it's not "clunky" or "misplaced", but it definitely could have been shown off a little more. Speaking for this in a comparison, it would land closer to an original inspired UI, such as Dark Souls. Relatively simple to navigate, and basically gets the job done. Could have been better, but I've seen worse.Combat in this game lands incredibly close to that of a Fable game, the particles of Magic based skills/attacks are very similar to the style of that series. And the combat feel is smooth, and aaalmost clean. It has a bit of register and error when it comes to trying to scroll between weapons when you want to, and when you want to aim at an enemy while moving backwards, something that comes with most games. Just need to remember that these things occur. The actual skills and devices of combat in this game feel familiar to Continent of The Ninth Seal (C9 by Webzen), the skills are incredible and awe-inspiring! I really feel at home with this game, and there is always something new to accomplish, or experiment with. Lots to tinker with, lots of different ways to go about doing one single thing. Always new possibilities for your character progression, and every class tree is fun to play with. Needless to say this game userped the throne of my RPG Top 10.Feel like this game is for you? It should. It is worth the full price, believe me. It is always nice to get it on sale, just don't waste any time NOT playing this game :)

												This is pretty late to the game, since Kingdoms has been out for years now, but I think it's important to review a game I love this much. I have more hours into this game than almost any other, and for good reason. The story is pretty extensive, and the sidequests are mostly worth doing, unlike some more recent RPG's.Pros:-Good main storyline-Easy to learn combat system-Excellent DLC-A weapon crafting system that makes your efforts count-Ability to respec easily later in the gameNeutral:-Built-in level cap doesn't allow for maximized characters-Even without maxed abilities, the game isn't difficult to beatCons:-The side stories are extremely repetitive and predictable-Speed is heavily favored over powerI know not everyone will agree with some of my points, especially the last one. But those are my takes on it. I have played it all the way through, and have created many characters, and I have just loved it.

content:
r 30, 2016
												Initial review when halfway through the game:More epic than Torchlight, less epic than Morrowing/Oblivion/Skyrim.Although KoA is not as epic and deep as the other famous titles in this genre, and the battle mechanics take some time getting used to, I would highly recommend this game! KoA has a more linear storyline, with fast travels, character customization, quests that are easy to follow.Followup review:After 74.6 hours of play, and with the main quest completed, I felt exhausted. The first 40 hours of the game was fantastic, absolutely loved it. However, once you get to the 60% mark of the game, the whole thing starts to get repetative. I stopped doing side quests and did not bother reading the dialouge between characters. All I wanted to do was to complete the main quest. Probably because I used melee set-up throughout the game and hence the game got boring for me. I never tried the "mage" or "theif" set-ups (you can change set-ups anytime during the game). And at the 60% mark of the game, the world started to get really big. You had to waste 20+ seconds to run from the entrance of the building to reach someone.During combat, the camera tends to 'fly' around. I couldn't see what my character was doing and the actions of my enemies.That being said, I still enjoyed the game. The game was not difficult and I had no issues completing the game comfortably on 'normal' mode. The game not was buggy at all, apart from one insignificant side quest where I was not able to complete because it kept crashing my game when I tried to 'light up the cactus". Summary: Kingdoms of Amalur was definitely worth my money and time.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 2, 2015
												★★★☆☆When i was playing mass effect 2 on xbox 360, I had chance to play kingdoms of amalur (as KOA) demo version. And this demo game gave me a good time. So i bought this one. Anyway that's personal history. :) Return to the subject, 'KOA' presents the new fantasy world about 'Rule of Cycle', 'Immortal Fea', 'Crystal War', 'Fateless One'... and so on. And these things are showed with beautiful graphic (not mean good quality).Also this game contains many thing to do. After tutorial, you will be faced a lot of quests. Even sometimes these quests make me confusing. You can collect regents or shards to create potions or gems. And you can breakdown equipment and salvage gears to make weapons or armors.And battle system is good. Even this is a RPG game. You can against your enemy by combo, air combo, combat ability and reckoning mode. Various weapons, skills, destinies (like specialized jobs) give you joyful choice. Even you think 'I made a wrong choices', don't worry, you can return to level 1 with all skill points. And reckoning mode is awesome, you become a powerful one and you can do fate-shift (like finish blow). I always felt catharsis when i finished a strong enemy by fate-shift.But 'KOA' also has bad things. First and Worst thing is '38 Studios (developer of 'KOA') was closed without 'KOA' licence sold. That means no more updates, DLCs and 'Kingdoms of Amalur II' :(And character customization is awful. May be, you have bad feeling, when you make your player. Because character customization has very little selections to make your face. Then your worry become a problem of game play. You can see  a NPC what have exactly same your face with different hair color. But that's not a problem, i can imagine he is a my doppelganger or unknown my brother who was seperated at childhood (in game story). But real problem is same faces NPCs are too many to focus story line. For example, You will meet a mentor who guide you in arcana faction quest, and he will send you to the archimage. (I skip many things to prevent spoiler). Then... you will see a same mentor face archimage with white hair. WTF, Even they are major NPCs of faction quest, they have same face!!! except hair color!!!! This problem will teases you until final battle.Other thing is the low level cap. If you are a person who complete all quest in the game (not repeat quests), you can reach level 40 (max level), soon. In my case, i could reach level 40 after siege of mel senshir. Probably i could do that because i finished 'The Legend of Dead Kel' and 'Teeth of Naros' before cross the ocean. Then i lost my purpose of side quests and battles. Level cap must be higher than level 40 to make player can push forward.Anyway 'KOA' is a good RPG game. If it was not, i didn't get all achievements of this game. 'KOA' is a new IP game what has potential to be a great franchise game. But it's a shame, future of 'KOA' is unclear.

content:
y 1
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning (KoA) is probably one of the best games I've ever played and ever will. Soon after you fall down into a pile of bodies and miraculously come back to life your pitted in a war against the people of Amalur and the Tuatha. The Tuatha are a race of the Fae that have been corrupted. You start with one area gathering armor, weapons, supplies, allies, ingredients, crystals, and other different nouns and items. There is a great leveling up system that gives you unique and different abilities. I never got the hang of dispelling or lock-picking so I'd recommend upgrading those early so you can force them. Let's also talk about how there are lore stones that give you background information on the land around you. You'll enjoy your time in KOA from becoming a witches husband or the hero of the Warsworn. There's also a achievement if you talk to someone with nothing equipped so that's cool. If you'd like to discuss more about the game feel free to friend me. It's worth whatever amount of money you pay for it. Rate 10/10 Rank The Best

												Alright, well, here we go, I bought this game under the impression it was open world, and had RPG elements, which it did have on both accounts, HOWEVER, After playing for 20 hours I came to a realization, this game is monotonous, it feels like ive been doing the same side quest 50 TIMES, the main story itself was intriguing, and combat is fairly fluid and dynamic, the class system in this game is different to say the least.To summarize, I came away from this game the same way I came away from Skyrim, its alot of fun, until you do everything, the choices you make have no real consequence, and the world seems HUGE on the map, but the reality is, its just large open (or semi-closed) spaces with the same brands of monsters scattered throughout the world at large, there is a backstory, but your so caught up in everything, you dont see it, I recomend this game when its onsale (for like 10$) but otherwise 7/10

												This is close enough to Fable to make me want to play it, but far enough away with enough minor issues in just the right places to make it annoying. It's so close to being a great game, but it just isn't. This game was written by my favorite writer: R.A. Salvatore.This game's art was directed by my favorite comic book arist: Todd Macfarlane.One of the creator's of Morrowind's engine was responsible for this game's engine, and I loved Morrowind.I wanted this to succeed more than anyone, but it fell flat. It has the repetition of an MMO, but without the other players to fill that void. The combat is decent, but not good enough to make up for the repetition. The characters are mildly interesting, and the voice acting is good. I would even say the graphics hold up even in 2017 because of the art style they chose. I just keep waiting for the point where I get immersed in the world, and it just isn't happening.

												Underdog detected :)PROS- Truly HUGE world.- An amazing amount of quests, a lot to do- Three classes with that play very differently because of their skills- High polish and optimisationCONS - Weird to say but the game is so huge that sometimes it can be discouraging :) But this is not really a con, mostly we have been playing short games for so long that we lost the attention span required to play a game for weeks.- Some of the lore can be boring sometimes. I find the fae to be a boring race for exemple, bunch of broken record playing the same songs again and again. But it fits the story and the world setting, i just wish there were more diversity in the culture of the world.REVIEWThis is a huge game and deserves a long review, but lacking the time suffice to say that it is an excelent RPG, and fairly unique in the way it tastes like an MMO because of its scale.I am not sure why this title didn't do better, I can't recall but i think at the time it came out there were 3-4 big titles coming out also and they completely overshadowed this game. I guess most people didn't have the budget or the gaming time for another 60$ title. I only grabbed this recently because it went on sale, and certeinly don't regret it. I got about 90 hours out of it already after finishing it (not a full clear mind you, a lot of quests and some exploration still left over), and I still have the DLCs set aside.Some advice : If you get slightly bored in your play, respecialize as another class. I went through all the 3 classes in my single playthrough, and it helped keep things fresh. The game certeinly doesn't warrant a playthrough with each class as it would be too repetitive, so might as well experience all classes on the same go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
												Do you want a game that could be compared as the arcade feeling The Elder Scrolls with with too many side quests to deal with? Then this game is right for you. At the start, you were a dead person, and resurrected by a gnome. Eventually you will be fated to be three archetypes: Warrior (representing Might), a Rogue (representing Finesse), or a Sorcerer (representing Sorcery). During your time, you may swap points around any, or all three of these fields to get a nice mix-match of what kind of character you want to build. Sounds great at the start, but sadly the further you go to see a pattern of go to this region and do mindless side-quests that may get you so sidetracked that you may forget what you were meant to be doing with the main storyline. Especially in my case when I took a year long break because of said mindless sidequests.Combat system is not that bad, but it is not that great either. You are allowed to hold two weapons at a time, yet both, or any of the weapons do have a limiting combo system. Best way to describe is just pressing X X X or B B B with a hint of X "pause" X "pause" X. Catch my drift. Too bad the baddies in the game do not hold up in the variety party. Could be a good thing when you do not have to remember how enemies attack, and can anticipate any attacks.After the combat comes the spoils, and it feels like the loot got spoiled. In the beginning, when you have nothing to use everything is great loot. By the time you come around your twenties or thiry levels the look; much like any dungeon crawler, can be sparse in quality. Even the armor sets could not hold a candle to some of the blue or even green armors that I had been picking up which makes you wonder if picking the lock of an average or higher difficult chest is worth the trouble.Speaking of lock picking; there are skills you can either pick up from leveling or some NPCs that you meet along the way. Most of these NPCs may only teach you so much in skill levels that it can be hard to find ones that can teach you further deep into the high ranks; even at areas where it should be level appropriate. Otherwise, most of the skills can you help you further into your adventure especially one to find all the hidden goodies. I did wish the crafting skills could make armor that would of been your end all to be all armor or weapons.Pros:+ You got PLENTY to do+ Though limiting archetypes, but you can mix them up+ Gorgeous world even at this point of the review it still holds up well.+ Decent skill system with worth while skills to achieveCons:- Too many side quests, but it is up to you if you want to bother- Lackluster loot at the end, and crafting weapon and armor is not much worth it. Shame...- Not much variety of enemies, and not much variety of a combat systemEven though I said a fair share of gripes with this game, but I did played through to the end, even if it was a bit painful if you are one that wants to finish all the quests. Without a middle recommendation, I am still going to recommend, but during a sale.

content:
11, 2016
												Don't let my low game hours fool you. I played this game for over 100 hours on my xbox before I wiped it.[Slight Spoilers]Pros:+This game lets you play whatever build you want to do.     -> Do you want to be a Mage and surprise people by slamming them to the ground with a massive warhammer? Do you want to play a Rogue who uses Daggers for assassinations but can hold her own in normal combat by wielding a Longsword? Do you want to play a Warrior who's only goal is to destroy people in insane combos with a sword that's twice their size? If you answered yes to any of these, please keep reading.    -> Each class has a set of weapons and armour associated with it, as well as abilities. A Rogue, for example, is built on skill points invested into Finesse and uses light/medium armour that gives bonus critical hit damage. Rogue weapons are the Bow, Daggers, and Faeblades. Their abilities are varied between sustaining mana to apply poison damage to all of their weapons to raining arrows from the sky.    -> The Warrior class is built on skill points invested into Brutality and can use Longswords, Greatswords, and Hammers with the heaviest armour that improves damage resistence and blocking ability. Their abilities vary from an adrenaline surge to deal massive damage when close to death to lifting all surrounding enemies into the air and slamming them all down.    -> The Mage class is built on skill points invested into Magic and can use Staves, Septres, and Chakrams with Robes for armour that help improve mana regeneration. Their abilities can vary from chaining lighting to summoning a meteor to crash down on enemies.+Gives the middle finger to restricted builds with the Destiny system.    -> You are not set to one way of playing the game. Just purchase a reset from a Fateweaver and suddenly, you can rebuild your character in their entirety! Go from a Mage in robes with a Staff and Septre to a hybrid Warrior/Rogue who uses a Hammer and Faeblades! (Keep in mind that there are many abilities to each class and you can do more than one class, or even all of them at once if you wanted. When you level up, read up on everything in your abilities tab and decide how the game should work for you.)+Super satisfying stealth gameplay.    -> Say you were spotted by a Jottun (a reverse Dwarf as I like to call them.) You can teleport through them, throw a smoke bomb down, jump on their back from stealth, and stab their neck to oblivion only to backflip off as you watch them bleed out. It's not just the massive enemies that are satisfying to stealth kill! You can sneak up on a Bandit and in quick succession you can trip them, making them land on their back only for your character to cover their mouth and stab their chest. The sneaking mechanic itself is a little bit wonky but oh my gosh it's still amazing to assassinate half of a Tuatha scout party and have the last few left ♥♥♥♥ talk you only to get torn to bits by open combat; speaking of which, my next point is close to this one.+Fluid combat system.    -> My favourite build was on my character named "Lorabella." She was a Warrior/Rogue hybrid that used a Longsword and Daggers. In the span of a minute, she can roll behind an enemy in stealth, backstab them, and immediately turn to the other enemies that spotted her afterwards. From here she can toss a smoke bomb or use an invisibility potion to get more stealth kills, or she can hold a weapon's attack (you can only equip two weapons at a time) and use the charge ability to launch herself at the nearest enemy, starting an attack combo which kills them quickly. After that, she can block with her shield at the right moment to deflect an enemy's attack and turn it into a combo to kill them quickly. I could go on and on about how many different ways you can play the same game and still be satisfied, but I will spare you from that.+Fateshifting.    -> In a tight spot? Too many enemies and you just want to go to the next area quickly? Want to get bonus XP for doing what you already do to kill enemies? Just do it™+Fast Travel!!!    -> Seriously who doesn't like this feature?Some cons: -The game can feel very repetitive.    -> Bandits, Fae, some Gnomes here and there, Jottun, Etten, Spiders, Kobolds, and so on. There's not much for diversity in enemies to face, some are just slightly different reskins of the base creature that does something different. See: Kobold Savages are Kobolds that throw their spears instead of try to poke you with them.    -> A lot of the game's quests are a variation of "go here and kill these things for me" and while the combat system is very fun, there's only so much that can be done before it feels like a chore. -Short story.    -> Excluding the time spent running to the new locations, the Faction quests as well as the main quests feel a little short compared to the size of the world given to the player.(Overall, I would say this game is absolutely worth buying. I haven't gotten to the DLCs yet though I do look forward to it! I hope this review helped!)-KEM

ry 20
 Currently at the time of reviewing this game it is on sale for $5 and all of its DLC $6. 	This game is definitely worth the price because of two reasons:1. The Combat2. The time it takes for completion  $5 = atleast 5 hours but in this case you get 200PROS +AMAZING COMBAT - Its combat is truly amazing it has great fluidity and just overall is extremly fun without getting boring. I just wish there were more skills for me to try.GRAPHICS - Although this game was released in 2012 its graphics still look good with a really colourful environment.OPENWORLD - Just a really nice touch for an rpg.LOOT - One thing that has always attracted me to rpg's is the loot/ special items you can find in them. KOA Reckoning does a phenominal job with having tons of  rare accessories, weapon and armor sets.TIME PLAYED - You can play this game for hours because of the sheer amount of quests and the size of its world.FACTIONS - You recieve special stuff when working with factions. The idea of factions is really cool and even though I like how you can work with all of them there isnt much story for them.REQUIREMENTS - Works great and doesnt require a top end gpu.CONS -STORY - Its story.... well all I can say is that it has one. The story is pretty lack luster and generic in my opinion and the npc's aren't really memorable either.CAMERA - You miss out on a lot of the beautiful environment because the camera angle is facing downwards on your character.RNG/BUGS - I've played through this game so many times looking for all armor sets but due to some unlucky bugs that make chests impossible to open I always quit halfway through due to frustration.BOSSES & Difficulty - The bosses in this game aren't really different from the monsters you fight regularily while playing through the game and the game itself is too easy even on the hardest difficulty._______________________________________________________________________________Overall this game is just great and  really fun to mess around in! I just wish that somehow, someway they can make a sequel to this game.

content:
3, 2014
												A really enjoyable ARPG with open-world feeling, crafting, and console-like combat. It would be easy for this game to fall into the trap of not doing anything well, but it's a lot of fun. There's some great voice acting with a pretty good story for immersion, satisfying combat and a decent amount of challenge. A ton of quests to do means you'll set off in one direction and get entwined in a town's story when you were intending to do something else, and that's a good thing. This is also the case with "shinies" on the ground - alchemical ingredients and loot chests. My path through the game makes me look like a drunken bumblebee.I highly recommend using a controller for this game - trying to use a keyboard gave me an epic frowny-face until I looked up whether it had controller support. It's much more intuitive that way, though you'll still need to glance at the controls listing from time to time when starting out.I received a bunch of OP-feeling gear when starting out, I think due to the complete DLC pack, but I happily received some upgrades fairly early on. Leveling occurs at a decent pace - enough to keep you feeling like you're getting somewhere, but not so fast you don't have time to stop and smell the roses.I almost feel guilty having gotten this game at 75% off during the Steam Summer Sale. This is a rare game that feels worth the retail price (especially since it was only $20 to begin with).

												The combination of rich lore inspired by Celtic and Gaelic mythology and the varied and engaging combat, I loved my experience in this game. I like the idea behind MMORPG games, but the execution falls short for me and the social component is more of a liability than an asset. Kingdoms of Amalur delivers on the promise of the MMO setting, and the ability to rebuild/respec your character from scratch was a great way to keep the experience fresh and engaging. While it doesn't warrant multiple playthroughs, once through gave me dozens of hours of fun and exploration. I just wish the player races had greater consequences.

content:
25, 2016
												EDIT: After playing more, I can safely say I do really enjoy this game. It's very charming in its own way and the world is pretty big. At the time of this review I've played about 30 hours and I'm only level 10 and still in the starting land!There are some bugs, the camera angle can be annoying at times, auto target is a bit wonky, I really dislike the short render distance (it was ported from consoles so the textures pop in at short distances... just annoying) But overall this is an "underrated" game if I ever saw one. It's a slightly flawed gem that should have gotten more attention. I was very sad to learn the studios went bankrupt after making this game because it didn't sell enough copies :( If it had gotten more attention it would have been given the love it deserves. The guy who made this game put all his savings and time into it and it "failed." So sad.PROS:-Pretty big world with about 10,000 years of backstory/lore (literally)-Graphics actually look pretty nice-"Cartoony" look sort of like Fable or Torchlight-Pretty good voice acting-SOOOO many quests and stuff to do! -Nice easy to learn skill system and flexible for any type of playstyle-Works 100% with a gamepad or controller (I myself use an XBOX controller)-RPG elements like a dialogue wheel and choices that affect quests/story-Unique story with a fairly interesting plot-Celtic mythology and lore which you don't see in many games(I myself am Irish so maybe I'm biased...)CONS:-Short render distance so textures pop in obviously all the time-Kind of weird camera angle FOV but there is a mod which fixes that-Some dialogue is a bit cheesy or repetitive now and then... but I find it hilarous :)-Silent main character... this is a con for me because it's quite awkward to have your character just stare at people during dialogue-Combat is a bit tricky.. sometimes it's difficult and sometimes too easy... Basic wolves and other "fodder" are the most annoying enemy in the game, while single bosses are easy peasy-Pehaps a bit too much reading, VERY dialogue and text heavy at timesI would still give it about an 8/10. If you like Skyrim, Fable, and Celtic mythology you would definitely enjoy this game :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 7, 2013
												An open world RPG with real-time combat and such a large indepth exp you will never get bored. But.... that does not mean its for everyone. It could be... but lets be honest... people get salty real easy these days.-lots of loot. Unique and Legendary items are everywere to be found and often well designed.-lots of quests. There a many stories to follow besides the main, and they follow the worlds tone well.-The main story isnt a life sim. Its not gonna rely on cheap ambiguety and bs to hold you. Its simple, fun, has a few twists that are reasonably predictable but fun. If you expecting DarkSouls or DragonAge then ♥♥♥♥ off and go play DarkSouls or DragonAge.-A simple yet well crafted skill-stat lvling system.-Item crafting, ranging from useless-overpowerd.-Combat is smooth and fun. Its got an arcade like feeling while still holding onto just enough depth to be a decent RPG. The abilities and skills, although based in commen ideas, are often presented in original ways.Now admittedly the game has a few middle fingers to spare. For one, theres no fireball spell... no thats a lie... theres no usable fireball spell. The NPCs get one. As well as a tornado and other stuff. They also get costums and one or two weapon types the player cant use. It doesnt break anything but its anoying... trying to think why the devs left that stuff out. Or why they left it in... for NPCs.I can understand NPCs, or bosses, having spcl attacks but the classic RPG Fireball. Its not even like its only one or to rare enemies either. Every enemy mage.All in all the games got a massive world, good story, and lots of fun combat to keep the average gamer going. I always reach a point where I need to put a game down and play something els, and although I have moved to other things, I never felt this game borring me. Maybe just me though...^_^9.5/10Note:-No co-op in a game this is perfect for it.-Although missions are fun and fighting is enjoyable almost everything is find and fetch or hunt and kill simple objective based goals. The story around said goals can be golden but, if you let it, it can turn into a grind. Not a 'hard' one mind you.

content:
r 9, 2014
												A review for this game may be pointless now. But I feel I need to praise this game for the immense enjoyment I got out of it since purchase. I will say three very positive things about this game.1 Combat balance: While it is true this game is super easy past level 20 or so, the "balance" I am talking about here is the balance between warrior/mage/rogue play styles. Unlike many other fantasy type games I've played, where your mage character usually gets much less choice in equipment compared to warrior/rogue types, here in this game, mages have the equal amount of variety in both weapon and armor selection, and some of the mage weapons are the most interesting ones I have ever played in any game. Reversely, in many other fantasy games, while warrior and rogue characters got more choices in equipment, they got shafted in spells they can use, this is again not true for this game. The rogue and warrior have a lot of interesting abilities they can cast around just like mages. This balanced playing style makes all three schools and any combination of the three feel refreshed and extremely fun for the majority of the game. And if you are like me who feel mages should have as much choice in equipment as other characters you are certainly going to love this game.2 Art style: Kingdoms of Amalur is probably the most gorgeous game I have seen for a very long time. While many mordern games may have better "graphics", they don't necessarily look any prettier. I am in the camp that firmly believes a good art design and style is more important than graphics and constantly find games from 1990s look better than games released in the past 10 years. And while the very particular bright and colorful art style of this game may not be for everyone, it is definitely the preferred style for me. And the game maps is carefully designed so you end up in many majestic positions in game to appreciate the view. Each major city in the game is grand and elegantly beautiful, each region has its own unique charm while all look amazingly appeasing all the time. In summary I think the art style is perfect in this game, if you love it at first sight you will love it for the remainder of the game.3 Sound track: While not many of the soundtracks stand out on their own, the magic thing here is that each of them goes along perfectly with the scenary. Good soundtrack in video games enhances the atmosphere and by that standard each music piece in this game is considered superb. Whether if it is charm, grandeur, danger or mystery the music in this game brings the mood out perfectly.To sum up, this is one of the most fun and beautiful game I have played in a long time. I hope whoever read this review can enjoy it as much as I do with this piece of epic gem.

ber 2, 2014
												I was wandering in a game store and picked up this for PS3 back in 2011. One of the best decisions ever.I know this game is not the best, but it's my most favourite RPG of all time, and I've been a long time fan of the genre.+ Good plot, not too complicated but still has its own complexity.+ At first I was a bit turned off by the cartoonish art style but it actually fits the game world really well.+ Beautiful music+ Huge map with lots of things to do+ Lastly, the combat system in this game is fantastic. Great variety of combat styles and they all fit with each other seamlessly. Until now the only game that could come close to this is Dragon's Dogma. + The factions in the game are very nicely designed. I really feel sad doing the quests of the House of Sorrows.+ The 2 DLCs are great, they add 2 very unique regions to the game.- There are quite a few game breaking bugs, as well as many minor bugs- The player character doesn't talk, thus making us feel a bit colorless. This is a common problem among the genre. Conversations are long and boring at times.- Monsters and loots are level locked the first time you enter a region. This discourages early exploring.Too bad we will never be able to see the sequel.9.5/10

												Essentially, this game is an EA verison of Elder Scrolls and just as incredible. I've only just begun playing this  game and I'm already taken in by it. From it's immersible gameplay to it's unrivaled scenery, the game is perfect, to say nothing of the epic weaponry. I'm only at Level 3 and I've already found three unbelieveable suits of armour, shields, and weapons. This game is well worth it's cost.

												Definitely one of the best ARPGs that came out recently.The combat system is really well done. Not only the control feels smooth, you are also given so much freedom to find your own play style. You can equip any two weapons and four spells at a time, and you can mix them however you want in combat. Not to mention the weapon crafting system and the gem crafting/socketing system that further enchance the customzation. Either you want to be Gandalf or Geralt of Rivia, it's all up to you. I think it is caused by the slight delay before your character makes a dodge, or I just suck at dodging. Hey, guess what, I can also block with my shield and it doesn't take a weapon slot.The blend of sword and magic and the stylish art style remind me of the Fable series. As far as combat goes, KOA:R definitely does it better than the Fable series. However I don't find KOA:R's story is intriguing enough for me. "Wow your fate is blank" "You'll save the world" blah blah blah. I still enjoy the gameplay, at least.One last thing, you can hide your helmet!! 10/10

content:
4, 2014
												A main storyline playthrough of the game itself is only 26 or so hours. Why the ♥♥♥♥ would I say ONLY? The game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (200+ hours) of content in sidequests and other content. 200 HOURS!! That's right, crazy. So you're sold on the amount of content, right? But what of the QUALITY. Well, I can confirm each quest, especially a ton of the side quests, has an interesting and unique story that fits into the huge ammount content in this lore filled world. Many of the side quests I've seen allow for alternate rewards and task changing interaction through fully voice-acted dialogue based around your pursuasion (charisma in other games) skill. (Making tue skill actually useful, unlike some games.) The character destiny cards systems encourages awesome hyhbrids of different combat styles and abilities from the three main branches where you can invest ability points. These cards are unlocked based on what trees you invest your AP to add bonus stats and even complete changes to your abilities to make yourself into the exact blend of abilities and strengths you desire.The combat itself introduces a number of skill based fighting mechanics that never seem to lose their weighty and epic feel. This is only added to in the fact that you can make any number of crazy class combinations to tailor your combat experience. Not to mention the weapon and gear options that are also complimented by the epic skills system.The complexity and depth added in the alchemy, blacksmithing, detect hidden, dispelling, lockpicking, mercantile, pursuasion, sagecraft, and stealth skills furthurs the great sense of benefit you get from investing in one skill each level. Each skill builds to greater perks as you invest furthur along in one particular skill, but the gut wrenching decisions you face in deciding where to invest next are what makes you realize the importance of each skill, and the role they serve.The progression of the game overall is at pretty much whatever pace you play at. If you want to rush to train for that next ability, do it. You will be fine, although you might want to bring some extra potions. If instead you want to do some side quests and join guilds for added benefits and rewards, do it. In fact, you can maintain a balance of both. The only qualm (not even that) I have is that if you progress to a furthur area and return to do some quests, they can in some cases seem too easy after becoming more powerful. Which, I don't see it really as a game flaw, because it is just the nature of the RPG genre. For example: after having defeated a dragon and then returning to kill some slimes of any typical rpg would be a walk in the park.I've been through just the tip of the iceberg, and there lies a journey of trials and triumph awaiting you. So,please buy this game, not for me, but yourself. You'll be glad you did.

												I heard allot of good stuff about this game. It was kind of like the epidemic of everyone telling you over and over again to watch Breaking Bad. "You don't watch Breaking Bad!!! YOU HAVE TO WATCH IT!" and from 100 different people each week until you finally just give in and watch it and realise what the heck you was missing! This game was like that. Every corner I turn I was hearing "Have you played Reckoning yet??" "Dude you have to play Reckoning, Seriously!" So I finally said heck with it and bought it. And there has not been one single shred of regret. You may know how it is to have a ton of games you have purchased in your steam library and you play one for a while and get bored and go to the next for a while. And with so many games you can't fully get into one certain game. And kind of wish you was stuck with just one game so you would be forced to enjoy it without feeling like you are missing out somewhere else. Well this game here has pretty much did that for me. Because there is no other game out there right now comparable to this so my Steam library might as well only have reckoning on the list. One of those games where you are thinking about it constantly when you are out of the house and soon as you walk in the door you push the button on the computer to get it prepped for some playage. If you are an RPG and or Hack and Slash fan this game will be your best friend. You will be buying the T-Shirts and watching youtube videos and drinking out of a reckoning coffee cup you purchased from china off ebay. It really is a great game. 												It's a pretty average game. The Graphics and world building are top notch. The combat and balancing was unique but not fully engaging. It became monotonous and I just ran past most of the fights towards the end. I suggest this game to people who really like RPGs. The combat isn't bad, but it's not good. It was never balanced properly. So your character will be OP for about 90% of the game no matter what you pick. Combat is more of a pacing mechanic than a  meaty gameplay element. You'll find yourself simply running past enemies to fulfill quests since enemies become time sinks rather than challenges.It was the quintessential mediocre RPG. Not too good, not too bad, with proper pacing so you never get stuck doing something you don't want to do.

content:
2015
												KINGDOMS OF AMALUR HERE IT COMES THE RECKONINGKingdoms of Amalur was a surprisingly good fantasy game. It has a fluid and fun combat system. It has a generic but decent storyline. But best of all, it has good side quests. Some of them are even more interesting then the main storyline at times.What I liked most about Kingdoms of Amalur, personally... was how you could build your character in whatever way you wanted. You were not tied down to any restricted class. But you could cross-class between three different trees. Don't like what you ended up doing? No problem. You can re-spec your character at any time during the game. Gold is no object, as there seems to be an over abundance of it in the game. I finished the game with over 6 million pieces of dosh. If that gives you any idea how much money you can make in this.The story goes like this. Your character gets killed doing something he or she shouldn't have been. You come back to life by some mysterious means... and you have the ability to control fate. Now it's time for you to go off and save the world. So yeah that's cool and all. We've heard this kind of plot before. But what is best about the game is the journey through it and the quests you undertake throughout. This game has good beefy side quests with rich story and characters. You wont be wasting your time like with a certain other game that just recently came out.. something with Dragons. Dragon Day I think it was called. Anyway, you'll find that there is a ton to do in this game. If you're a nut about completion this'll take you a good 100 + hours to complete. SO clear you calender, ya dig?Weapons are cool. Each weapon has its own unique style and use. I suggest dicking around with all of them and seeing what you like best. I personally enjoyed the chakrams cause you don't see them much in games, and the daggers because they're the only weapons you can do killmoves with on a sneak attack.The game has a big flaw however and this is one I don't usually complain about with games.. but it was too easy. At level 20... 40 being the max.. I was nigh invincible. It's too easy! I played on normal difficulty, so I recommend maybe playing on Hard if you're not new to RPG's and third person action games in general.The DLCs were both great. Teeth of Narnia & Dead Kenan & Kel had a great storyline and plenty of extra and new content. I'd totally recommend picking up the complete package when it's on sale!So am I missing something? Probably. If you have any questions regarding the game, let me know and i'll answer them post haste.Finale Verdict: (4.4 out of 5)
